Period of time from about 10,000 years ago to today. During this period glaciers retreated because of a warmer global climate. Time of modern humans. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

A protective structure erected over railroad tracks to prevent deep snow from accumulating on the tracks. They are used in deep cuts in mountains where avalanches are common. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A layer of unfrozen ground that is perennially cryotic (t < 0 degrees Celsius), forming the basal portion of the permafrost. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A part of the seasonal ice zone that varies in width (100 to 200 kilometers, 62 to 124 miles) that extends from the ice edge into the ice pack, where waves and swells affect the ice; often characterized by highly variable ice conditions; in general, it is wider in the Antarctic than the Arctic. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A part of the seasonal ice zone that varies in width (100 to 200 kilometers, 62 to 124 miles) that extends from the ice edge into the ice pack, where waves and swells affect the ice; often characterized by highly variable ice conditions; in general, it is wider in the Antarctic than the Arctic. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A channelized accumulation of liquid water on (supraglacial), in (englacial), or under (subglacial) a glacier, moving under the influence of gravity. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

A general term for ice which has been squeezed together and forced upwards and downwards in places. Subdivisions are rated ice, ridge ice, hummocked ice, and other similar deformations. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
A general term for ice that has been squeezed together and, in places, forced upwards (and downwards). Subdivisions are rafted ice, ridged ice, and hummocked ice. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}

A general term for ice which has been squeezed together and broken up with formation of surface and underwater conglomerations. Subdivisions are rafted ice, rough ice, ridged ice, jammed brash barrier and hillocky multiyear ice. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

Sea ice terminology. It is a general term for ice which has been squeezed together, and in places, forced upwards and downwards. The subdivisions of deformed ice are known as rafted ice, ridged ice, and hummocked ice. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
A general term for sea ice that has been broken and reoriented. It includes ridged, hummocked, and rafted ice. Deformed ice is distinguished by its high surface roughness. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The cumulative number of degree-days above 0˚C for a given time period, calculated from the mean monthly temperatures for a specific station without making corrections for negative degree-days in spring and fall #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A linear accumulation of glaciofluvial outwash sediments found in a once glaciated valley. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The portion of the cooling of a human body caused by air motion. Air motion accelerates the rate of heat transfer from a human body to the surrounding atmosphere, especially when temperatures are below about 7C (45F). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A snowflake composed of many individual ice crystals. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A thin, dry snow surface which is composed of loose, fresh ice crystals. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Dry snow surface which is composed of loose, fresh ice crystals. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
A skiing term for a cover of dry snow that has not been compacted in any way. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A thin, dry snow surface which is composed of loose, fresh ice crystals (cf. New snow). #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Form of permafrost that exists at high altitudes in mountainous environments. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

Area scaling A method of relating glacier volume or volume changes to glacier area or area changes, based on a tendency for glacier thickness to be well correlated (to 'scale') with glacier area. Glacier volume V is the product of area S and mean thickness H. Measured mean thicknesses are well described by a relation of the form H c S1, which is the basis for the volume-area relation V c S . Here c and are parameters estimated from samples of glaciers with measured thicknesses. There is good evidence, as shown by Bahr et al. (1997), that estimates of from observations are nearly consistent with theoretical expectation. Mean thickness is also sometimes estimated as a function of average surface slope and basal shear stress. Volumearea scaling is both a way of estimating regional and global glacier volumes from abundant data on glacier area, and a possible way of estimating (with large random uncertainty) the volume balance of single glaciers from successive measurements of area S1 and S2, for example as2 1 ()2(2V c S S . It can also be used, as a practical alternative to ice-flow modelling, to estimate glacier area changes in attempts to model the response of glaciers to climatic change. Glacier volume is also expected, and found, to scale with glacier length, particularly when the length is that of a flowline. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A public product issued by the RFC containing narrative and numeric information on river ice conditions. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Vertical depth of the water layer which would be obtained by melting a snow cover. (TR) #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
The depth of water that would result from the melting of a snow cover; may be expressed either at a point or as an areal average. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Ice formed by reverse sublimation of water vapour on cold surfaces. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice formed by reverse sublimation of water vapour onto cold surfaces #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A body of earth material moved or disturbed by frost action. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A body of earth material moved or disturbed by frost action #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A wedge-shaped body of sand produced by filling of a thermal contraction crack with sand either blown in from above or washed down the walls of the crack #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A form of ice wedge that contains accumulations of wind blown sand in long vertical layers. A form of periglacial ground ice. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Agglomerations of snow crystals. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
The advancing boundary between thawed ground and frozen ground. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The advancing boundary between thawed ground and frozen ground #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Saltation is the mechanism by which snow particles are eroded from or deposited onto the snow surface and transported by the wind near to the surface. The process involves particles bouncing downstream and shattering new particles from the snow surface (King et al., 2008). #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

Unconstrained by topography Continental size Derive their morphological shape from ice flow properties, internal dynamics, and bedrock conditions Inundates areas of Continental size May incorporate individual ice domes #{g: xqGLIMSGlacier | h1627}
(Or frost dam.) A ditch constructed to assist the early and rapid freezing of the soil in order to block the seepage of subsurface flow from entering a critical area. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A glacier experiencing glacier flow. Expansion or retreat is determined by the balance between mass accretion and mass depletion processes. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
A glacier experiencing glacier flow. Expansion or retreat is determined by the balance between mass accretion and mass depletion processes. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The elevation of the surface of a floating ice body above the surface of the water in which it is afloat. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

The cumulative number of degree-days, calculated by adding all the negative mean daily air temperatures (degrees Celsius) for a specific station during a calendar year. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The cumulative number of degree-days, calculated by adding all the negative mean daily air temperatures (˚C) for a specific station during a calendar year #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Any method of determining the mass balance that involves measurement or calculation of glacier flow, including the flux-divergence method, the kinematic-equation method and methods in which the mass balance is determined as the sum of the discharge through a cross section and the surface mass balance of the region upglacier from the cross section. Information about density is needed to convert the volumetric fluxes obtained by kinematic methods to mass fluxes. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Similar to a headland, but of larger extent, that may be above open sea, above an ice piedmont or above an ice shelf. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

Displacement of ice floes and other ice features resulting from the impact of wind and currentsincluding tidal currents and of forces transferred through the ice cover from other regions. The drift direction and velocity of a specific ice feature or ice cover area depends at any specific moment on themagnitude of the external forces, on the feature #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
Movement of ice fields or floes in lakes and reservoirs, caused by wind or currents. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
Movement of ice fields or floes in water bodies caused by wind or currents. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Glacial drift is the loose and unsorted rock debris distributed by glaciers and glacial meltwaters. As glaciers melt, their remaining load of rocks is distributed in several ways. Rocks may be dropped in place by the melting ice; they may be rolled to the ice margins, or they may be deposited by meltwater streams. Collectively, these deposits are called 'glacial drift'. 'Till' refers to the debris deposited directly by the glacier. Rock debris rolls off the glacier edges and builds piles of loose unconsolidated rocks called 'glacier moraine'. 'Lateral moraines' form along the side of a glacier and curl into a 'terminal moraine' at the glacier's downvalley end. Drift and moraines are valuable to geologists because they outline the boundaries of past glaciations. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

All rock material in transport by glacial ice, and all deposits predominantly of glacial origin made in the sea or in bodies of glacial meltwater, including rocks rafted by icebergs. "Glacial drift occurs as scattered rock fragments, as till [rocks mixed with finer material], and as outwash [fine material with no rocks]. Contrast with angular drift."(from Glossary of Arctic and Subarctic Terms 1955). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A generic term applied to all glacial and glaciofluvial deposits. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
A thick coating of rime formed on windows and other surfaces. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The advance of a freezing front upwards from the permafrost table during annual freezing of the active layer. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The advance of a freezing front upwards from the permafrost table during annual freezing of the active layer #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The process of mountain building through tectonic forces of compression and volcanism. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
An unglacierized area abutting on a glacier margin. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A type of precipitation composed of slowly falling, very small, unbranched crystals of ice which often seem to float in the air; it may fall from a high cloud or from a cloudless sky, it usually occurs under frosty weather conditions (under very low air temperatures). #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

An optically and physically thin layer of ground-level cloud composed of small ice crystals that settle slowly. Typically diamond dust forms by the mixing of relatively moist air from aloft into a low-level inversion layer in which the temperature is 40 #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Diamond dust forms under very low air temperatures in strong, surface-based temperature inversion layers. Either vertical mixing within or radiational longwave cooling of this layer causes the air to become supersaturated with respect to ice, so that small ice crystals form. These mostly unbranched crystals are seemingly floating in the air, slowly falling from an often apparently cloudless sky (AMS, 2000). Columns (ppco) and plates (pppl) are the dominant shapes found in diamonddust (Walden et al., 2003), but stellar dendrites (ppsd) may also be observed. Long-prism columns having a ratio of length to width 5 are defined as 'Shimizu crystals'. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
Ice that has been floating and has been deposited on the shore by retreating high water. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology describing ice which had been floating and is then deposited on the shore by retreating high water. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

An ice crystal usually having an aspect ratio greater than 2 and as much as 100 and with hexagonal symmetry, although trigonal (threefold) and occasionally other symmetries occur. As such crystals fall through the clouds in which they form, they may encounter conditions causing them to develop dendritic extensions, that is, become plane-dendritic crystals. (Or platelet.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

An ice crystal usually having an aspect ratio greater than 2 and as much as 100 and with hexagonal symmetry, although trigonal (threefold) and occasionally other symmetries occur. As such crystals fall through the clouds in which they form, they may encounter conditions causing them to develop dendritic extensions, that is, become plane-dendritic crystals. (Or platelet.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
An area of floating ice of any size, which is greater than 10 km across. The characteristics, position and sizes of fields are described as separate zones. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

A continuous accumulation of snow and glacier ice that completely fills a mountain basin or covers a low-relief mountain plateau to a substantial depth. When the thickness become great enough, tongues of ice overflow the basins or plateaus as Valley Glaciers. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
Area of pack ice consisting of floes of any size that are greater than 5.5 n mi (10 km) across. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology that describes an area of floating ice, consisting of floes greater than 10 km across. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
A large, level area of ice, either of sea ice ("more than five miles across") or an ice cap or highland ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Large level area of glacial ice found covering a large expanse of land. Similar in size to an ice cap but does not have a dome-shape. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Very intense showers of snow, often of short duration, that greatly restrict visibility and produce periods of rapid snow accumulation. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ridge with peaks slightly rounded and slope of sides usually 30 to 40 degrees. Individual fragments are not discernible. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology describing a ridge with peaks slightly rounded, and slope of its sides that is usually 30 to 40 degrees. Individual fragments of ice are not visible. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The character of land currently covered by glacier ice (cf. Glaciated). #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Land overlaid at present by a glacier is said to be covered; the alternative term glacierized has not found general favour. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Of a region or terrain, containing glaciers or covered by glacier ice today. See glaciated, which refers to past coverage. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
See recrystallization zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A polynya that forms from strong winds in a persistent direction that push the ice away from a barrier (the coast, fast ice, a grounded iceberg, or an ice shelf). #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Areas where prevailing onshore winds are responsible for heavy snowfall is known as a snowbelt, and usually refers to regions southeast of open water. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Ice formed by the freezing of liquid precipitation or the freezing of melted solid precipitation (see snow depth) #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Ice formed in a smooth thin layer on a water surface by the coagulation of frazil through rapid freezing. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Sea ice terminology that describes submerged ice that is attached or anchored to the bottom of the sea, irrespective of the nature of its formation. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

The southern front of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, also known as the antarctic convergence, that separates the Antarctic Zone in the south from the polar frontal zone in the north. It is characterized by sea surface temperatures near 5-6C and a salinity minimum of 33.8-34.0 psu produced by high rainfall. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The southern front of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, also known as the antarctic convergence, that separates the Antarctic Zone in the south from the polar frontal zone in the north. It is characterized by sea surface temperatures near 5-6C and a salinity minimum of 33.8-34.0 psu produced by high rainfall. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Hexagonal ice crystals with complex and often fernlike branches. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Commonly used abbreviation for iceberg. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The ELA at the end of the mass-balance year. The Annual ELA is not in general the same as the average altitude of the Annual snowline. The superimposed ice zone lies below the Annual snowline and above the Annual ELA. However, if there is no superimposed ice, the Annual snowline can be used as a proxy for the Annual ELA. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A fan-like deposit at the base of a slope, produced by solifluction #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Precipitation in the form of snow from a convective cumulus-type cloud, are known as flurries. They are characterized by the suddenness with which they start and stop, by their rapid changes in intensity, and usually by rapid changes in the appearance of the sky. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The layer of ground above permafrost; it includes the active layer and possibly occurrences of talik and pereletok. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A snow water equivalent gage based on the absorption of gamma radiation by snow; this gage can measure up to 55 inches water equivalent with a 2 to 5 percent error. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

A tiny ice particle, about 10-20 microns in diameter, formed by direct freezing of supercooled water droplets with little growth directly from the vapor. The term combines the words drop and crystal. Droxtals cause most of the visibility reduction in ice fog. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
An irregularly shaped iceberg. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
An irregularly shaped iceberg. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

Refers to the roughness of a snow surface caused by precipitation or the wind as well as by uneven evaporation, sublimation, or melt. It does not refer to roughness due to snow microstructure. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

Crack caused by significant changes in water level. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
Crack caused by significant changes in water level. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
Depression of sea floor applied in this work to such a feature beneath an ice shelf. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

Snow metamorphism that builds angular facets on crystals and makes cup and scroll shaped crystals. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
Snow metamorphism that builds angular facets on crystals and makes cup and scroll shaped crystals. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Relatively high hills or mountains. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

A recording rain gauge in which the weight of water collected is measured as a function of time and converted to rainfall depth. The weight-sensing mechanism is typically mechanical (springs). The output can be a pen trace on a strip chart, voltage from a potentiometer, punched paper tape, or other electronic means. Weighing gauges with continuous output can be used for determining rainfall rate and depth. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The output can be a pen trace on a strip chart, voltage from a potentiometer, punched paper tape, or other electronic means. Weighing gauges with continuous output can be used for determining rainfall rate and depth. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The thickness at which ice no longer grows because it is so thick that heat from the ocean can no longer be conducted through the ice; it may take several years of growth and melt for ice to reach an equilibrium thickness. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A mineral soil showing little or no evidence of cryoturbation, with permafrost within 1 meter (3.3 feet) below the surface. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A mineral soil showing little or no evidence of cryoturbation, with permafrost within 1 m below the surface #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Snow covering the ridges and peaks of mountains when no snow exists at lower elevations. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The average of the minimum altitude and maximum altitude of the glacier. The mid-range altitude is of interest in itself as a measure of the vertical location of the glacier, but has also been shown to be (to within the accuracy of measurements) an unbiased estimator of the Balanced-budget ELA. See glaciation level. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Top or summit applied to a hill, mountain or nunatak. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

A graph of the area-altitude distribution; hypsographic curve is a synonym. The hypsometric curve shows the area-altitude distribution by plotting area on the horizontal axis versus altitude on the vertical axis. Intervals on the altitude axis are commonly 25, 50 or 100 metres. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Pertaining to an object in physical contact with, or close to, the glacier margin. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Date on which ice forming a stable winter ice cover is first observed on the water surface. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
A patterned ground feature with a step-like form and a downslope border of stones embanking an area of relatively fine-grained bare ground upslope. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A sorted step is a patterned ground feature with a step-like form and a downslope border of stones embanking an area of relatively fine-grained bare ground upslope #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The melting from below of any floating ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Thinning of the glacier due to ablation. See dynamic thinning. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The thinning of a glacier due to the melting of ice. This loss of thickness may occur in both moving and stagnant ice. Also called Thinning. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

A more or less symmetrical zone of frozen ground formed around a buried chilled pipeline or beneath or around a structure maintained at temperatures below 0 degrees Celsius. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A more or less symmetrical zone of frozen ground formed around a buried chilled pipeline or beneath or around a structure maintained at temperatures below 0˚C #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Any polar area permanently covered by ice and snow, with no vegetation other than occasional red snow or green snow. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Instrument for measuring the depth to which the soil is frozen. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
A polynya between pack ice and the coast, or between pack ice and an ice front. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology describing a polynya between ice and the coast, or between ice and an ice front. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

(1) The act of compacting earth, soil clay, etc., by mixing them with water and rolling or tamping the mixture. (2) A compact mass of earth, soil, clay, or a mixture of material, which has been compacted through the addition of water, rolling and tamping. This makes the material less permeable. (3) A small pool of water, usually a few inches in depth and from several inches to several feet in it greatest dimension. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

An accumulation of melt water on an ice surface, mainly due to melting snow, but in later stages also to the melting of ice; the initial stage consists of patches of slush. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

An accumulation melt-water on ice, mainly due to melting snow, but in the more advanced stages also to the melting of ice. The initial stage consists of patches of melted snow. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

An accumulation on ice of meltwater, mainly due to melting snow, but in the more advanced stages, also to the melting of ice. Initial stage consists of patches of melted snow. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}

In hydrologic terms, (1) The act of compacting earth, soil clay, etc., by mixing them with water and rolling or tamping the mixture. (2) A compact mass of earth, soil, clay, or a mixture of material, which has been compacted through the addition of water, rolling and tamping. This makes the material less permeable. (3) A small pool of water, usually a few inches in depth and from several inches to several feet in it greatest dimension. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

Sea ice terminology that describes an accumulation of water on ice, mainly due to melting snow. However, in the more advanced stages puddles can also be due to the melting of ice. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Accumulation of meltwater on ice, mainly due to melting snow and, at a later stage, the melting of ice. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
An accumulation of melt water on an ice surface, mainly due to melting snow, but in later stages also to the melting of ice. The initial stage consists of patches of slush. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
A ridge in which the base has frozen together. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology, describing a ridge in which the base has frozen together. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Soil in which segregated ice will form (causing frost heave) under the required conditions of moisture supply and temperature. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Soil in which segregated ice will form (causing frost heave) under the required conditions of moisture supply and temperature #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A surficial layer of angular shattered rocks formed in either modern or Pleistocene periglacial environments #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A navigable passage between pack ice and fast ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A passage-way between pack ice and fast ice which is navigable by surface vessels [Note: shore lead is used in the Antarctic] #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
A passageway between pack ice and fast ice that is navigable by surface vessels. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology, describing a passageway between ice and fast ice, which is navigable by surface vessels. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
A navigable passage between pack ice and fast ice. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

The renewal of the mass of a glacier by mass-balance processes. Mass turnover is measured most usefully by the mass-turnover time, which is the mass of the glacier divided by the mass-balance amplitude, with the latter expressed as an Annual rate. Mass-turnover times range from several decades for glacierets to tens of thousands of years for ice sheets. See response time. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

The renewal of the mass of a glacier by mass-balance processes. Mass turnover is measured most usefully by the mass-turnover time, which is the mass of the glacier divided by the mass-balance amplitude, with the latter expressed as an Annual rate. Mass-turnover times range from several decades for glacierets to tens of thousands of years for ice sheets. See response time. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

The formation of discrete layers or lenses of segregated ice in freezing mineral or organic soils, as a result of the migration (and subsequent freezing) of pore water. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The formation of discrete layers or lenses of segregated ice in freezing mineral or organic soils, as a result of the migration (and subsequent freezing) of pore water #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The formation of discrete layers or lenses of Segregated Ice in freezing mineral or organic soils, as a result of the migration (and subsequent freezing) of pore water. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}

A type of snow crust; a patch of hard-packed snow that is packed as it is deposited in favored spots by the wind (in contrast to wind crust, which is packed after deposition). Wind slabs can be quite rigid, but they adhere poorly to the underlying snow and hence may be readily dislodged, causing an avalanche. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Close, clear-cut ice edge compacted by wind or current; usually on the windward side of an area of pack ice. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology that describes a clear-cut ice edge that is compacted by wind or current, usually on the windward side of an area of ice. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The mechanical disintegration, splitting or break-up of rock by the pressure of water freezing in cracks, crevices, pores, joints or bedding planes. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The mechanical disintegration, splitting or break-up of rock by the pressure of the freezing of water in cracks, crevices, pores, joints or bedding planes #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A process of physical weathering in which water freezes in a crack and exerts force on the rock causing further rupture. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
An ice field over 12 n mi (20 kin) across. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology describing an ice field that is over 20 kilometres across. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

A type of hoarfrost that is formed on the windward side of terrestrial objects and on aircraft flying from cold to warm air layers. Ice feathers are made up of single, columnar ice crystals, some of which grow out from others at large angles and thus build up a delicate spatial array of tiny crystals. (Also called frost feathers.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

(Also called frost feathers.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The approximate center of the most consolidated portion of the arctic pack ice near 83S or 84N, and 160W. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The entire width of the tongue terminates on dry ground; Irregular or single lobe frontal line #{g: xqGLIMSGlacier | h1627}
A less-used synonym of activity index, appearing mainly in the Russian-language literature. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Submerged frazil ice attached or anchored to the river bottom, irrespective of its formation. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
Submerged ice which is attached to the bottom. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Submerged ice found attached to underwater objects such as the channel bed and aquatic vegetation. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

Ice attached to the beds of streams, lakes, and shallow seas, irrespective of its nature of formation. On clear, cold nights in relatively still water, anchor ice may form directly on submerged objects. It also develops in supercooled water if turbulence is sufficient to maintain uniform temperature at all depths, in which case a spongy mass of frazil accumulates on objects exposed to rapid flow, and later deposition fills in the pores and creates solid ice. When the water temperature increases to above 0C, the ice rises to the surface, often carrying with it the object on which it had accumulated. Sometimes anchor ice is erroneously called ground ice, a term which should be reserved for bodies of more or less clear ice in frozen ground. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Submerged ice which is attached to the bottom. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

An oligochaete worm that lives on temperate glaciers or perennial snow; there are several species that range in color from yellowish-brown to reddish-brown or black; they are usually less than 1 millimeter (0.04 inch) in diameter and average about 3 millimeters (0.1 inch) in length; some feed off red algae. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The sliding of a glacier over bedrock. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The sliding of a glacier over bedrock, a process usually facilitated by the lubricating effect of meltwater. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The motion of the basal ice of the glacier relative to the material immediately beneath the glacier. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The sliding of a glacier over the surface it rests on. Caused by the gradient of the slope and the weight of the glacier's mass. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

(1) with respect to both shape and size of snow grains, the same as particle, i.e., the smallest characteristic subunit of snow microstructure recognizable with a hand lens (8-10x magnification). (2) One single crystal of ice making up the ice structure of snow. The crystal orientation is continuous across each individual grain. Several grains together form a polycrystal having grain boundaries where crystal orientation changes. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground, overlain and underlain by perennially frozen ground. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground, overlain and underlain by perennially frozen ground #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Pack ice in which the floes are tightly packed but not frozen together, with very little, if any, sea water visible; ice cover practically 10/10th. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Floating ice in which the concentration is 9/10 and more, but less than 10/10. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
Pack ice in which the concentration is nine-tenths to less than ten-tenths. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Pack ice in which the floes are tightly packed but not frozen together, with very little, if any, sea water visible. Ice cover practically 10/10ths. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Snowstorm occurring on the shore of a lake or downwind from a lake, arising as a result of the modification of the air during its passage over the water. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

Snowstorm occurring near or downwind from the shore of a lake resulting from the warming (destabilization) and moistening of relatively cold air during passage over a warm body of water. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Precipitation, usually of brief duration, consisting of crisp, white, opaque ice particles, round or conical in shape and about 2 to 5 mm in diameter. Same as graupel or small hail. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

Instrument which uses a source of gamma radiation positioned on a surface underlying a snow cover to measure the amount of radiation absorbed by the snow and hence determine the water content of the snow. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

An instrument designed to determine the water content of snow by measuring the amount of gamma radiation absorbed by the snow overlying the transmitter that is placed at the surface. Because the earth naturally emits gamma radiation, by the same concept, aircraft measurements of gamma radiation can be used to estimate the water content of snow on the ground along the aircraft's flight path. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Ground (soil or rock) in which segregated ice will form (causing frost heave) under the required conditions of moisture supply and temperature. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ground (soil or rock) in which segregated ice will form (causing frost heave) under the required conditions of moisture supply and temperature #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A method for estimating glacier surface velocities by measurement of the positions of easily distinguishable features on repeated images of known date. See speckle tracking. Surface debris and crevasses are the most commonly measured features. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Hydrothermal alteration is the alteration of rocks or minerals due to the reactions of geothermally heated water with minerals. The process weathers and weakens the rocks such that they may become unstable. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

1.Defined by W. Köppen (1931) as the zone having a definite winter with snow, and a short summer, generally hot. It includes a large part of North America between the Arctic Zone and about 40N, extending to 35N in the interior. In Central Europe and in Asia the boreal zone extends southward from the tundra to 40-50N. 2.A biogeographical zone or region characterized by a northern type of fauna or flora. The term boreal region is used mainly by American biologists, and includes the area between the mean summer isotherm of 18C or 64.4F (roughly 45N latitude) and the Arctic Zone. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

An accumulation of aerosol that, when deposited on the surface of a glacier, modifies the mass balance through its effect on surface albedo. Saharan dust, for instance, sometimes has a substantial impact on the mass balance of European glaciers. Volcanic eruptions can deliver dust and ash to nearby, and sometimes to distant, glaciers. In extreme cases the added material can turn the glacier into a debris-covered glacier. Dust can help to define the summer surface, and a dateable dust layer in firn or glacier ice can be useful as a marker horizon. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

An accumulation of aerosol that, when deposited on the surface of a glacier, modifies the mass balance through its effect on surface albedo. Saharan dust, for instance, sometimes has a substantial impact on the mass balance of European glaciers. Volcanic eruptions can deliver dust and ash to nearby, and sometimes to distant, glaciers. In extreme cases the added material can turn the glacier into a debris-covered glacier. Dust can help to define the summer surface, and a dateable dust layer in firn or glacier ice can be useful as a marker horizon. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A period 12.85 to 11.65 ka (thousand years before 1950), during the deglaciation, characterized by a temporary return to colder conditions in many locations, especially around the North Atlantic. #{g: xqIPCC2013 | h1631}

The period from approximately 10 800 to 9600 BC when climate in the region around Greenland cooled by 5-7C within a few decades and recovered with similar rapidity at the end of the period; named for the expansion of the geographic range of the arctic herb Dryas octopetala. Evidence is accumulating for a wider, perhaps global, extent, but the Younger Dryas was most strongly felt around the North Atlantic Ocean. Changes in the thermohaline circulation of the oceans are widely believed to be implicated in the onset and ending of the Younger Dryas cooling. These were in turn associated with a switch to the St. Lawrence River as the major route for meltwater reaching the North Atlantic from the retreating continental ice cap. Other similarly rapid oscillations in climate are recorded through much of the last glacial in ice cores from Greenland and in marine sediment cores from the North Atlantic (Dansgaard-Oeschger events). The period since the Younger Dryas (the Holocene) lacks such extreme excursions. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Vertical distance between the top surface of a snow layer and the ground beneath; the layer is assumed to be evenly spread over the ground which it covers. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
Vertical interval between the top surface of a snow layer and the ground beneath; the layer is assumed to be evenly spread over the ground which it covers. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Vertical distance between the top of a snow layer and the horizontal ground beneath. The layer is assumed to be evenly spread on the surface. When the snow is not uniformly distributed, snow depth is measured by taking an average of multiple measurements #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The vertical distance between the surface of a snow layer and the ground or ice beneath; average or representative depth for the area. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

Growth of a cloud or precipitation particle by the collision and union of a frozen particle (ice crystal or snowflake) with a supercooled liquid droplet which freezes on impact. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

(1) Growth of a cloud or precipitation particle by collision with supercooled liquid droplets that freeze wholly or partially on impact. (2) The process by which a layer of ice or snow builds on solid objects such as overhead lines that are exposed to precipitation icing events. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

Any one of a number of macroscopic, crystalline forms in which ice appears, including hexagonal columns, hexagonal platelets, dendritic crystals, ice needles, and combinations of these forms. The crystal lattice of ice is hexagonal in its symmetry under most atmospheric conditions. Varying conditions of temperature and vapor pressure can lead to growth of crystalline forms in which the simple hexagonal pattern is present in widely different habits (a thin hexagonal plate or a long thin hexagonal column). In many ice crystals, trigonal symmetry can be observed, suggesting an influence of a cubic symmetry. The principal axis (c axis) of a single crystal of ice is perpendicular to the axis of hexagonal symmetry. Planes perpendicular to this axis are called basal planes (a axes related to the prism facets) and present a hexagonal cross section. Ice is anisotropic in both its optical and electrical properties and has a high dielectric constant (even higher than water) resulting from its water dipole structure. The electrical relaxation time for water is much shorter than for ice (10^9 Hz compared with 10^4 Hz), resulting from a chain reaction requirement for molecules to relax through defects in the ice lattice. In the free air, ice crystals compose cirrus-type clouds, and near the ground they form the hydrometeor called, remarkably enough, "ice crystals" (or ice prisms). They are one constituent of ice fog, the other constituent being droxtals. On terrestrial objects the ice crystal is the elemental unit of hoarfrost in all of its various forms. Ice crystals that form in slightly supercooled water are termed frazil. Ice originating as frozen water (e.g., hail, graupel, and lake ice) still has hexagonal symmetry but lacks any external hexagonal form. Analysis of their sections (0.5 mm) in polarized light reveals different crystal shapes and orientations, depending on the freezing and any annealing and subsequent recrystallization process. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Is an environment that is located close to the Ice front of a Glacier, Ice Cap or Ice Sheet. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
A term formerly used in the stratigraphic system (Anonymous 1969; Appendix: A) for Annual ablation. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Frozen precipitation of particles of either spherical or conical ice; their diameter is about 2 to 5 mm. They are brittle, easily crushed, and unlike hail, when they fall on hard ground, they bounce and often break up. Snow pellets always occur in showers and are often accompanied by snow flacks or raindrops when the surface temperature is around 0 #{g: xqCanadaNCA | h1624}
Precipitation in the form of small, white opaque ice particles; resemble ice grains, but are round (sometimes conical) and about 2-5 mm in diameter. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Form of permafrost that exists across a landscape as an unbroken layer. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

Snow pellets are brittle and easily crushed; when they fall on hard ground, they bounce and often break up. They always occur in showers. They are often accompanied by snow flakes or rain drops, when the surface temperature is around zero Celsius. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Precipitation of white and opaque ice particles, which fall from a cloud and which are generally conical or rounded, with diameters attaining as much as 5 mm. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

Precipitation consisting of white, opaque, approximately round (sometimes conical) ice particles having a snowlike structure, and from about 2 mm to less than 5 mm in diameter. (Also called soft hail, graupel, tapioca snow.) Snow pellets are crisp and easily crushed, differing in this respect from snow grains. They rebound when they fall on a hard surface and often break up. In most cases, snow pellets fall in shower form, often before or together with snow, and chiefly on occasions when the surface temperature is at or slightly below 0C (32F). It is formed as a result of accretion of supercooled droplets collected on what is initially a falling ice crystal (probably of the spatial aggregate type). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A form of precipitation also known as graupel. Snow pellets are white, spherical bits of ice with a maximum diameter of 5 millimeters. Snow pellets develop when supercooled droplets freeze on snowflakes. Snow pellets often fall for a brief time period when precipitation transforms from ice pellets to snow. Snow pellets can be easily distinguished from packed snowflakes as they tend to bounce when they strike the ground. Packed snowflakes are not dense enough to cause them to bounce. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

Process that occurs when wind, ocean currents, and other forces push sea ice around into piles that rise and form small mountains above the level sea ice surface; ridges are initially thin and transparent with very sharp edges from blocks of ice piling up; also see keels. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
1. See ridge. 2. A ridge of ice, up to 35 m (100 ft) high and sometimes several kilometers long, in pressure ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A peaty permafrost mound possessing a core of alternating layers of segregated ice and peat or mineral soil material. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A peaty permafrost mound possessing a core of alternating layers of segregated ice and peat or mineral soil material #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A mound of peat that develops as the result of the formation of a number ice lenses beneath the ground surface. Typical size is 1 to 7 meters high, 10 to 30 meters wide, and 15 to 150 meters long. Found in the high latitudes. Similar to a pingo. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Ice is said to nip when it forcibly presses against a ship which is beset; a vessel so caught, though undamaged, is said to have been nipped. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice is said to nip when it forcibly presses against a ship. A vessel so caught, though undamaged, is said to have been nipped. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Ice is said to nip when it forcibly presses against a ship. A ship so caught, though undamaged, is said to have been nipped. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
Sea ice terminology. Ice is said to nip when it forcibly presses against a ship. When a vessel is caught in this way, though undamaged, it is said to have been 'nipped.' #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Ice is said to nip when it forcibly presses against a ship which is beset. A vessel so caught, though undamaged, is said to have been nipped. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

Natural elevation rising to a relatively great height. Mountain, hill and knoll are terms indicating various degrees of height in descending order, varying with the general configuration of the vicinity. The term mountains may be used for a grouping within a range. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

Relatively fast uniform winds concentrated within the upper atmosphere in a narrow band. The polar jet stream exists in the mid-latitudes at an altitude of approximately 10 kilometers. This jet stream flows from west to east at speeds between 110 to 185 kilometers per hour. Also see jet stream and subtropical jet stream. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Relatively fast uniform winds concentrated within the upper atmosphere in a narrow band. The polar jet stream exists in the mid-latitudes at an altitude of approximately 10 kilometers. This jet stream flows from west to east at speeds between 110 to 185 kilometers per hour. Also see jet stream and subtropical jet stream. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The most recent time (15 000 to 80 000 years ago) during which continental glaciers covered subpolar regions and existed at elevations as much as 1000 m lower than today; corresponding to periods in which oxygen isotopes from marine sediment cores indicate that global sea level was 50-150 m lower and global temperature 5-10C lower than today. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The most recent time (15 000 to 80 000 years ago) during which continental glaciers covered subpolar regions and existed at elevations as much as 1000 m lower than today; corresponding to periods in which oxygen isotopes from marine sediment cores indicate that global sea level was 50-150 m lower and global temperature 5-10C lower than today. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The part of the accumulation zone of a cold glacier or polythermal glacier where all of the snow reaches the melting point during the ablation season. The wet-snow zone is sometimes referred to as the lower percolation zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Circulation of flow about a horizontal or nearly horizontal axis that is usually associated with flow over the lee side of a barrier, such as a mountain range. The rotation may extend to the ground, cause hazards to aircraft, and carry large amounts of dust aloft. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
An agglomerate of loosely packed frazil which floats or accumulates under the ice cover. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
In hydrologic terms, an agglomerate of loosely packed frazil which floats or accumulates under the ice cover. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
A mass of ice which has detached itself from a steep glacier and which is descending on to the terrain below. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Landforms and soil characteristics produced by periglacial processes. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Landforms and soil characteristics produced by periglacial processes #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A feature of hard snow formed by wind. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Disarticulation is the process through which large blocks of ice, sometimes greater than .5 miles in width, detach from the thinning and retreating terminus of a glacier that ends in a body of water. Disarticulation occurs as the terminus thins to where its buoyandcy no longer permits it to remain in contact with its bed. As the glacier begins to float free and rises off the bottom it rapidly comes apart along old fracture scars and crevasses. For example, at Bering Glacier, in the Chugach Mountains, Alaska, a single observed disarticulation event resulted in nearly 2/3 of a mile of terminus retreat in a single day. As many as 100 discrete, tabular pieces of glacier ice have been observed separating from the glacier's terminus in a single event. Bering Glacier flows through Wrangell-St. Elias National Park, Alaska. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Hummocked grounded ice formation. Single grounded hum- mocks occur as well as lines (or chains) of grounded hummocks. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology. Defines a hummocked, grounded ice formation. There are single grounded hummocks and lines (or chains) of grounded hummocks. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The lower part of the ablation area of a valley glacier, commonly shaped like the snout of an animal. In North America, the term toe is more widely used. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Front end of a glacier. Also called the terminus. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
The region within the Arctic Circle, or, loosely, northern regions in general, characterized by very low temperatures. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
A region of perpetual snow. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The smallest characteristic subunit of snow microstructure recognizable with a hand lens (8-10x magnification); a particle can consist of one or more crystals of ice (see also grain). #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
The difference between the elevations of the ground surface before and after the occurrence of frost heave #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A crevasse pattern that forms where ice slowly spreads out sideways; commonly found near a glacier terminus. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

The cumulative number of degree-days above 0 degrees Celsius, calculated by taking the average of the seasonal thawing indices for the three warmest summers in the most recent 30 years of record. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Old snow which has been transformed into a dense material. Firn is characterized by the fact that: (a) the particles are to some extent joined together, but that (b) the air interstices still communicate with each other. (a) distinguishes it from snow and (b) from ice. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Old snow which has been transformed into a dense material. Firn is characterized by the fact that: (a) the particles are to some extent joined together, but that (b) the air interstices still communicate with each other. (a) distinguishes it from snow and (b) from ice. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

An isolated, tongue-shaped solifluction feature, up to 25 m wide and 150 m or more long, formed by more rapid solifluction on certain sections of a slope showing variations in gradient #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Permafrost that formed through a rise of the permafrost table during the deposition of additional sediment or other earth material on the ground surface. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Permafrost that formed through a rise of the permafrost table during the deposition of additional sediment or other earth material on the ground surface #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The volumetric balance flux divided by the area of the vertical cross section through which it passes. Comparison of balance velocity to actual velocity, that is, to the actual volumetric flux (mass flux divided by average density) divided by the area of the vertical cross section, gives an indication of the health of the glacier. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Floating ice formed in lakes. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice formed on a lake, regardless of observed location. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology describing ice formed on a lake, regardless of where it ends up. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Floating ice formed in lakes. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
Ice formed on the surface of a lake. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Floating ice formed in lakes. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

A boulder swept from its place of origin by glacier advance or retreat and deposited elsewhere as the glacier melted; after glacial melt, the boulder might be stranded in a field or forest where no other rocks of its type or size exist. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A meltwater stream that has penetrated below the surface of a glacier and is making its way towards the bed. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The rate of ice accumulation on an aircraft is such that de-icing/anti-icing equipment fails to reduce or control the hazard. Immediate diversion is necessary. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Water occurring in the pores of soils and rocks #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A temporary lake, dammed by a glacier or where two glaciers merge. Prone to seasonal catastrophic drainage. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
A lake that exists because its water is restricted from flowing by an ice dam. Sometimes these lakes form because an advancing glacier had blocked a valley. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

Geographic area in which permafrost occurs everywhere beneath the exposed land surface with the exception of widely scattered sites, such as newly deposited unconsolidated sediments that have just been exposed to the freezing climate; mean annual soil surface temperatures are typically below -5 degrees (23 degrees Fahrenheit). #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Permafrost occurring everywhere beneath the exposed land surface throughout a geographic region with the exception of widely scattered sites, such as newly deposited unconsolidated sediments, where the climate has just begun to impose its influence on the thermal regime of the ground, causing the development of continuous permafrost #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Permafrost occurring everywhere beneath the exposed land surface throughout a geographic region with the exception of widely scattered sites, such as newly deposited sediments, where the climate is just beginning to influence the ground thermal regime, causing the development of Continuous Permafrost. For practical purposes, the existence of small Taliks within Continuous Permafrost has to be recognized. The term, therefore, generally refers to areas where more than 90% of the ground surface is underlain by Permafrost. The term 'continuous' Permafrost is mostly used for Arctic/Antarctic Permafrost zones. For the mountainous zones the terms 'likely, possible and unlikely' are preferred. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}

Fog which forms in the lower part of a relatively moist and warm air mass as it moves over a relatively cooler water surface. This process cools the water vapour to such an extent that it condenses into the suspended water droplets that create the fog. It reduces visibility to less than one-half (1/2) nautical miles. (See also advection fog). #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Moraine built out ahead of an advancing glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A ridge or pile of unstratified glacial sediment that is formed in front of the ice margin by the terminus of an advancing glacier, bulldozing sediment in its path. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

A complex landform ranging from a few metres to tens of metres in height comprising assorted debris that has been pushed up by a glacier during an advance. Push moraines are best developed in front of polythermal glaciers. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Geomorphological features of varying scale produced by the process of solifluction #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

High pressure system located in the upper atmosphere at the polar regions. In this system, air in the upper troposphere moves into the vortex center and then descends to the Earth's surface to create the polar highs. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The term polar vortex is used to describe several different features in the atmosphere. It most commonly refers to a planetary-scale mid- to high-latitude circumpolar circulation. There are distinct tropospheric and stratospheric circumpolar vortices. The tropospheric polar vortex is usually defined by geopotential contours that lie within the core of the tropospheric westerlies.1 The tropospheric vortex edge is generally between 40˚ and 50˚ latitude (Fig. 1), and the vortex exists throughout the year but is strongest during winter when the air within the polar vortex is the coldest. The term 'polar vortex' is sometimes used in reference to smaller-scale (meso- to synoptic scale) vortices that usually occur within the tropospheric polar vortex in polar regions near the tropopause - for example, tropopause polar vortices. 2. The stratospheric polar vortex exists from spring to fall and usually extends from just above tropopause to the upper stratosphere (see Fig. 1). The stratospheric vortex generally increases in size from the lower stratosphere to the upper stratosphere where its edge is located around 50˚ latitude. The stratospheric vortex breaks down, and the circumpolar flow reverses, during summer. 3. Circumpolar vortices have also been observed on other planetary bodies (e.g., Mars, Venus, Saturn, and Titan). 4. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The large-scale cyclonic circulation in the middle and upper troposphere centred generally in the polar regions. syn. circumpolar vortex #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
The additional ground ice formed as a direct result of permafrost aggradation. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The additional ground ice formed as a direct result of permafrost aggradation #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Ground Ice formed as a direct result of Permafrost Aggradation. Ice lenses form seasonally, especially in the lower part of the Active Layer, and can be incorporated into the Permafrost if they do not melt over a period of years. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}

The cumulative number of degree-days above 0˚C, calculated by taking the average of the seasonal thawing indices for the three warmest summers in the most recent 30 years of record #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A decrease in the separation between individual ice floes resulting in increased ice concentration. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
The cryostructure of a frozen deposit of angular blocks that are coated with ice, whereas large spaces between the blocks are not filled with ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The cryostructure of a frozen deposit of angular blocks that are coated with ice, whereas large spaces between the blocks are not filled with ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

During a period of glacier recession, back from a terminal moraine, a lake may form. This lake is impounded by an unstable pile of debris and buried ice. Catastrophic failure of the moraine will result in a devastating flood. Usually associated with high mountain regions such as the Andes and Himalaya. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

During a period of glacier recession, back from a terminal moraine, a lake may form. This lake is impounded by an unstable pile of debris and buried ice. Catastrophic failure of the moraine will result in a devastating flood. Usually associated with high mountain regions such as the Andes and Himalaya. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

Precipitation consisting of a mixture of rain and wet snow. It usually occurs when the temperature of the air layer near the ground is slightly above freezing. The British term for this mixture is sleet (which has a different meaning in the United States). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A harbor, inlet, etc. Is said to be ice-bound when navigation by ships is prevented on account of ice, except possibly with the assistance of an icebreaker. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
A harbor, inlet, etc., is said to be ice bound when navigation by ships is prevented on account of ice, except possibly with the assistance of an icebreaker. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Ridge newly formed with sharp peaks and slope of sides usually 40 degrees. Fragments are visible from the air at low altitude. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology that describes a ridge with sharp peaks and sides that has a slope of 40 degrees or more. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

A model which simulates snow pack accumulation, heat exchange at the air-snow interface, areal extent of snow cover, heat storage within the snow pack, liquid water retention, and transmission and heat exchange at the ground-snow interface. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

In hydrologic terms, a model which simulates snow pack accumulation, heat exchange at the air-snow interface, areal extent of snow cover, heat storage within the snow pack, liquid water retention, and transmission and heat exchange at the ground-snow interface. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Glaciofluvial sediments deposited by meltwater streams at the edge of a glacier. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The observed, or model calculated age categories of ice and their partial concentrations. The sum of the partial concentrations of ice of different age should be equal to the total ice concentration in the given zone. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

Large scale sinking of the crust into the asthenosphere because of an increase in weight on the crustal surface. Common in areas of continental glaciation where the crust was depressed by the weight of the ice. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The movement of the solid part of the earth until it is in balance; also called isostatic compensation. The prime example of isostatic adjustment is the continents "floating" on the denser parts of the crust. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A distinct soil micromorphology, resulting from the effects of freezing and thawing processes, in which coarser soil particles form circular to ellipsoidal patterns #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A radar, usually a pulsed system with one transmitting and one receiving antenna, operating at a frequency suitable for imaging the subsurface. In glaciology, low frequencies (2220 mhz) are suitable for ice thickness measurements whereas higher frequencies of several hundred mhz are suitable for snow thickness measurements, including detection of the current summer surface and older Annual layering (see radar method). Higher frequencies yield better resolution but may not allow very deep penetration; lower frequencies exhibit the reverse properties. Choice of frequency is therefore paramount. Radar imaging of the subsurface relies on accurate determination of the two-way travel time of the radar wave, which depends on the density. Reflections are caused by contrasts in the (complex) relative dielectric constant at interfaces between layers. Illustrative values of the real part of the relative dielectric constant, at frequencies used by ground-penetrating radars, are 1 for air, ~3.15 for pure ice, ~10 for bedrock and 88 for water at 0 #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

An ice-wedge polygon in which thawing of ice-rich permafrost has left the central area in a relatively depressed position #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Climate during periods prior to the development of measuring instruments, including historic and geologic time, for which only proxy climate records are available. Palaeoclimate #{g: xqEU-ADAPT | h1626}

Climate for periods prior to the development of measuring instruments, including historic and geologic time, for which only proxy climate records are available. (Or geological climate.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Destruction of the ice cover on rivers before break-up, due to the impact of flood waves or ice breaking away from the banks. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
See infiltration-recrystallization zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A prominent ridge of glacial debris formed when a glacier reached its maximum limit during a sustained advance. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The extreme relief of ablation hollows found most often at high altitudes in the tropics; the resulting spikes of snow resemble repentant souls. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Permafrost containing neither free water nor ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Permafrost containing neither free water nor ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Permafrost containing neither Free Water nor Ice. A negligible quantity of moisture in the form of interfacial water may be present. Dry Permafrost is thaw-stable (cf. Thaw Weakening). #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
Permafrost that contains little or no ice; it is loose and crumbly. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A northerly foehn wind blowing down the Italian side of the Alps. The northern slopes are normally cooler than the southern slopes, and the dynamic warming is often insufficient to overcome the difference of temperature. Hence a warm dry northerly wind of foehnlike character occurs less frequently than the south foehn. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
