A jetlike northward looping excursion of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current east of southern Argentina; also known as the Falkland Current. Somewhere between 33 and 38S it meets the Brazil Current and turns eastward, forming an intense temperature and salinity front. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A discontinuity in the annual layering in firn or ice, resulting from a period when ablation cuts across successive layers. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Pressure due to a moving ice cover or drifting ice. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

A glacier containing some cold ice and some temperate ice. Classically, as first described, a polythermal glacier has a basal layer of temperate ice overlain by a layer of cold ice (panel a in Figure 9), above which there may be a surface layer up to about 1015 m thick that warms to the melting point seasonally. See cold glacier, temperate glacier. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A thermally complex glacier with both warm and cold ice (q.v.). Typically, warm ice occurs where the ice is thickest as a result of geothermal heating, whilst the snout and margins of the glacier are frozen to the bed. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
(1) Transformation of snow into liquid water. (2) Water from the melting of snow. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
Melting of the snowcover, and also the period during which melting of the snow cover occurs at the end of the winter. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Melting of the snowcover, and also the period during which melting of the snowcover occurs at the end of the winter #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Melting of the Snow Cover, and also the period during which melting of the Snow Cover occurs at the end of the winter. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
The water resulting from the melting of snow. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The fissure at the line of junction between an immovable icefoot or ice wall and fast ice, the latter being subject to the rise and fall of the tide. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A crack between fast ice subject to sea level tidal rise and fall and the fast ice foot or ice wall, or shore. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
Crack at the line of junction between an immovable ice foot or ice wall and fast ice, the latter subject to rise and fall of the tide. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
A crack between the moving sea ice and the unmoving ice foot. It may widen to form a shore lead. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The fissure at the line of junction between an immovable icefoot or ice wall and fast ice, the latter being subject to the rise and fall of the tide. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Physiological damage to plants and plant tissues during occurrences of frost with temperatures generally below 3C. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A type of glacial drift that has been partially sorted by glaciofluvial meltwater. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
The distance from the ground surface downward to the level beneath which there is practically no annual fluctuation in ground temperature. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The distance from the ground surface downward to the level beneath which there is practically no annual fluctuation in ground temperature #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The distance from the ground surface downward to the level beneath which there is no annual fluctuation in ground temperature. A change of no more than 0.1C throughout the year is arbitrarily considered as 'practically no annual fluctuation'. In the Northern hemisphere the temperature at the Depth of Zero Annual Amplitude ranges from about -0.1C at the southern limit of the Permafrost region to about -15C in the extreme polar reaches of the zone of Continuous Permafrost. The Depth of Zero Annual Amplitude varies widely but generally lies between 10 and 20 m below the ground surface, depending on climatic and terrain conditions such as amplitude of annual surface temperature variation, vegetation, Snow Cover and characteristics of the soils and rocks including thermal diffusivity. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
The properties of the ground governing the flow of heat through it, and its freezing and thawing conditions. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The properties of the ground governing the flow of heat through it, and its freezing and thawing conditions #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The properties of the ground governing the flow of heat through it, and its freezing and thawing conditions. The position of the interface between thawed and frozen soil with respect to the ground surface, for a given surface-temperature regime, depends on the thermal properties of the strata located above and immediately below the interface. The basic Thermal Properties of Frozen Ground are Thermal Conductivity, Heat capacity and Latent Heat of Fusion. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
The cumulative number of degree-days below 0 degrees Celsius for a given time period. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A measure of the combined duration and magnitude of below freezing temperatures occurring during a specific freezing season and calculated by accumulating the number of degree-days below 0 degrees C and subtracting from that total the number of degree-days above 0 degrees C over the same period. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
The cumulative number of degree-days below 0˚C for a given time period #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

As used by the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers, the number of Fahrenheit degree-days (above and below 32F) between the highest and lowest points on the cumulative degree-days time curve for one freezing season. For a critical review of the topic see Sakari Tuhkanen (1980). "The freezing index is used as a measure of the combined duration and magnitude of below freezing temperatures occurring during any given freezing season. The index determined for air temperatures at 4.5 feet above the ground is commonly designated as the air freezing index, while that determined for temperatures immediately below a surface is known as the surface freezing-index." (Also called "coldness sun.") #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
That portion of a glacier where a sudden steepening of descent causes a chaotic breaking up of the ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The cumulative number of degree-days below 0C for a given time period. Four main types of air freezing indices have been used: Approximate Freezing Index - calculated from the mean monthly air temperatures for a specific station without making corrections for positive degree-days (T > 0C) in spring and fall (Boyd, 1979); I_af = SUM (NT) where N = number of days per month for months with a mean monthly temperature below 0C during one complete year. T= mean monthly temperature. Total annual Freezing Index - calculated by adding all the negative mean daily air temperatures (C) for a specific station during a calendar year (Harris, 1981); I_af = SUM (T) where T = mean daily air temperatures (C) below 0C for one complete calendar year. _ Seasonal Freezing Index - calculated as the arithmetic sum of all the negative and positive mean daily air temperatures (C) for a specific station during the time period between the highest point in the fall and the lowest point the next spring on the cumulative degree-day time curve (Huschke, 1959); I_af = SUM (T) where T = mean daily air temperatures (C) during the time period between the highest temperature in the Fall and the lowest temperature in the Spring. _ Design Freezing Index - calculated by taking the average of the seasonal freezing indices for the three coldest winters in the most recent 30 years of record. If data for 30 years are not available, then the index is based on the coldest winter in the latest 10-year period of record (U.S. Army/Air Force, 1966). #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
Horseshoe-shaped snowdrift, with the ends pointing down-wind. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Horseshoe-shaped snowdrift, with the ends pointing down-wind. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Effects of frost action on earth materials and on structures placed in or on the ground. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Effects on earth materials and on structures placed in or on the ground, resulting from frost action #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The water mass formed in the Arctic Ocean by a combination of freezing on the arctic shelf and deep winter convection in the Greenland and Norwegian Seas. Freezing increases the salinity under the ice; the dense water sinks to the ocean floor and leaves the arctic basins to enter the Greenland and Norwegian Seas, where it mixes with water that sinks under the influence of surface cooling. The resulting water mass has a salinity of 34.95 psu and a temperature of -0.8 to -0.9C. It fills the Arctic Ocean at all depths below 800 m, the sill depth to the Atlantic. It enters the Atlantic in bursts, when the passage of atmospheric depressions lifts the thermocline and allows Arctic Bottom Water to flow over the sill. Overflow events in the Denmark Strait and across the Iceland-Faeroe sill contribute some 5 Sv (5 x 10^6 m3/s) to the formation of North Atlantic Deep Water. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The water mass formed in the Arctic Ocean by a combination of freezing on the arctic shelf and deep winter convection in the Greenland and Norwegian Seas. Freezing increases the salinity under the ice; the dense water sinks to the ocean floor and leaves the arctic basins to enter the Greenland and Norwegian Seas, where it mixes with water that sinks under the influence of surface cooling. The resulting water mass has a salinity of 34.95 psu and a temperature of -0.8 to -0.9C. It fills the Arctic Ocean at all depths below 800 m, the sill depth to the Atlantic. It enters the Atlantic in bursts, when the passage of atmospheric depressions lifts the thermocline and allows Arctic Bottom Water to flow over the sill. Overflow events in the Denmark Strait and across the Iceland-Faeroe sill contribute some 5 Sv (5 x 10^6 m3/s) to the formation of North Atlantic Deep Water. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The change in the volume of a glacier, or part of a glacier, over a stated span of time. A volume balance contains no information about the density of the matter within the volume gained or lost. It is meaningful in itself, but is often an intermediate product in the determination of mass balance by geodetic methods. Balances expressed in ice-equivalent or water-equivalent units, such as m3 w. E. A-1, are not volume balances but mass balances. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

No moraines: no moraines; Terminal moraines : terminal moraines; Lateral and/or medial moraine: Lateral and/or medial moraine; Push moraine: Push moraines are difficult to identify unambiguously by remote sensing techniques, because in satellite images they are often not distinguishable from 'normal' terminal moraines. The only way to identify push moraines is by ground observations; Debris, uncertain if morainic: Debris, uncertain if morainic; Moraines, type uncertain or not listed: Moraines, type uncertain or not listed; #{g: xqGLIMSGlacier | h1627}

(1) Climatic snowline: lowest altitude of a continuous layer of snow on the high mountains in summer. (2) Orographic snowline: lowest altitude at which snow persists on the land surface as isolated coverings on the mountains in summer. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

A set of points forming the lower limit of a snow-covered area; on a glacier, the line separating snow surfaces from ice or firn surfaces, and also separating the percolation zone from either the superimposed ice zone or the ablation zone (see also zone). The set of points need not form a continuous curve. The snow-covered area of the glacier may include outliers (isolated patches of snow surrounded by firn or ice) and may exclude inliers (isolated patches of exposed firn or ice). The snowline is usually easy to see, because the snow above it is brighter than the firn or ice below it. It may therefore be mapped by analysis of suitable imagery. When, and only when, there is no superimposed ice, the snowline coincides with the equilibrium line. Unless qualified by a different adjective, references to the snowline are understood to refer to the Annual snowline. It is common for 'snowline' to be used as an abbreviation of 'average altitude of the snowline'. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

In general the outer boundary of a snow covered area. This may be the ever-changing latitudinal limit of snow cover, particularly in the Northern Hemisphere winter, or the lower limit in altitude of the permanent snow cover in mountainous terrain. The latter strongly depends on the aspect of slope. Snowline should not be confused with snow level. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
The lower boundary of a highland region in which snow never melts #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Precipitation in the form of slowly falling, singular or unbranched ice needles, columns, or plates. They make up cirriform clouds, frost, and ice fog. Also, they produce optical phenomena such as halos, coronas, and sun pillars. May be called 'diamond dust.' Precipitation of ice crystals in the form of needles, columns or plates sometimes so tiny, they seem suspended in air. They are mainly visible when they glitter in sunshine and occur only at very low temperatures and stable air masses. #{g: xqCanadaNCA | h1624}
Any one of a number of macroscopic crystalline forms of ice including hexagonal columns and platelets, dendritic crystals, ice needles and their combinations. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

A barely visible crystalline form of ice that has the shape of needles, columns or plates. Ice crystals are so small that they seem to be suspended in air. Ice crystals occur at very low temperatures in a stable atmosphere. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

A collection of attributes serving to distinguish one part of the glacier from others; by extension, the part of the glacier so distinguished. The term, originally Latin for 'face, outward appearance', was borrowed from geology. Examples of diagnostic attributes include ice lenses in the firn, indicating refreezing and therefore the percolation facies; the absence of such lenses, possibly suggesting the dry snow facies; or the seasonal exposure of glacier ice, indicating the ablation facies. In glaciology the term zone is equivalent and is now more common. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Large chunk of glacier ice (a very small iceberg) floating in the sea; bergy bits are usually less than 5 meters (15 feet) in size and are generally spawned from disintegrating icebergs. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A large piece of floating glacier ice, generally showing less than 16 ft (- 5 m) above sea level but more than 3 ft (= 1 m) and normally about 120 to 360 sq yds (t 100-300 sq m) in area. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}

A large piece of floating ice of land origin, showing less than 5 m above sea-level and 100-300 m2 in area [Note: it might be better to say no more than 20 metres long, rather than give an area] #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}

A piece of ice which has broken away from an iceberg, extending 1-5 meters above the sea surface and 100-300 square meters in area. Can also be the remains of a melting iceberg. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

Sea ice terminology that describes a piece of glacier ice, generally showing at 1m to less than 5m above sea level; with a length of 5m to less than 15m. They normally have an area of 100-300 sq. M. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
A piece of floating glacier ice up to several metres across, commonly deriving from the disintegration of an iceberg. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
A small iceberg or iceberg fragment; it also may be a piece of floeberg or hummocked ice; it is larger than a growler. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A piece of floating ice, generally less than 5 m above sea level and not more than about to m across. It is generally of glacier ice, but may be a massive piece of sea ice or disrupted hummocked ice. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
A general term for all types of coarse clastic formations on slopes of 2-3 to 40 degrees, moving downslope mainly due to creep. #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A deposit consisting of decayed or partially decayed humified plant remains. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A deposit consisting of decayed or partially decayed humified plant remains #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Mass transfer by avalanches which redistribute snow, firn and ice. Avalanching from a valley wall to the glacier surface constitutes accumulation. Avalanching from the glacier margin constitutes ablation. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A local bowl-shaped region or depression in the surface in which, in suitable conditions, cold air accumulates during the night as the result of cold air drainage called katabatic wind. Such regions are subject to a greater incidence of frost, and to more severe frosts, than are the surrounding areas of nonconcave shape. (Also known as frost pocket in agricultural/gardening) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A heavily crevassed area in a glacier at a region of steep descent. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
A heavy snow shower accompanied by sudden strong winds. #{g: xqCanadaNCA | h1624}
A brief, but intense fall of snow that greatly reduces visibility and which is often accompanied by strong winds. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A moderate to heavy snow flurry, which is driven by strong, gusty winds. Visibility during snow squalls is usually poor. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

A snow squall is an intense, but limited duration, period of moderate to heavy snowfall, accompanied by strong, gusty surface winds and possibly lightning (generally moderate to heavy snow showers). Snow accumulation may be significant. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

(1) a general property of aqueous solutions caused by the alkali, alkaline earth, and metal salts of strong acids (Cl, SO4 and NO3) that are not hydrolyzed (2) in soil science, the ratio of the weight of salt in a soil sample to the total weight of the sample. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

1. A general property of aqueous solutions caused by the alkali, alkaline earth, and metal salts of strong acids (Cl, SO<SUB>4</SUB> and NO<SUB>3</SUB>) that are not hydrolyzed; 2. In soil science, the ratio of the weight of salt in a soil sample to the total weight of the sample. #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The process by which a solid changes phase into a liquid; a synonym of fusion. See ablation. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The physical process of a solid becoming a liquid. For water, this process requires approximately 80 calories of heat energy for each gram converted. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

A pinnacle of ice, shaped like a triangular sail, typically several metres high, formed as a result of differential ablation under strong solar radiation, mainly in low, but sometimes high-arid latitudes. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The bonding together of ice crystals. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

The process by which intergranular bonds form in a powder or porous material such as snow dry or wet, decreasing thereby the surface energy of the material. In dry snow, direct deposition of water vapour diffusing through the pore space is usually the dominant bond growth mechanism, but several other mechanisms may contribute depending on the prevailing conditions surface, volume, and grain boundary diffusion as well as plastic flow. Externally applied pressures, e.g., overburden by snow or ice, assist the sintering process by so-called pressure sintering. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

Sintering is the process whereby ice crystals adhere through the diffusion of water vapor from regions of positive curvature to regions of negative curvature, such as the boundary between the two crystals. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A bright white glare on the underside of clouds, produced by the reflection of light from a snow-covered surface; snowblink is lighter than ice blink, and much lighter than land sky or water sky. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Frozen ground with a very low total water content consisting almost completely of interfacial water, and not cemented by ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

The in-situ melting of glacier ice. Many glaciers have stagnant termini, covered by thick sediment debris. Some support vegetation, including mature forests. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
The in-situ melting of glacier ice. Many glaciers have stagnant termini, covered by thick sediment debris. Some support vegetation, including mature forests. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
Small droplets of highly saline water that form in pockets between ice crystals, as sea ice forms and expels salt into the underlying ocean water. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A strong northeast wind in Russia and central Asia. It is most frequent in winter when it resembles a blizzard, that is, very cold and lifting snow from the ground; as such it is called white buran or, on the tundra, purga. A similar wind in Alaska is called burga. The buran also occurs, but less frequently, in summer, when it raises dust clouds; it is then called karaburan. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A strong northeast wind in Russia and central Asia. It is most frequent in winter when it resembles a blizzard, that is, very cold and lifting snow from the ground; as such it is called white buran or, on the tundra, purga. A similar wind in Alaska is called burga. The buran also occurs, but less frequently, in summer, when it raises dust clouds; it is then called karaburan. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Treeless terrain, with a continuous cover of vegetation, found at both high latitudes and high altitudes. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A treeless biome characteristic of polar and alpine regions. #{g: xqIPCC2014 | h1632}
Treeless terrain, with a continuous cover of vegetation, found at both high latitudes and high altitudes #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Treeless plains that lie poleward of the tree line. (Also called arctic desert.) The plants thereon are sedges, mosses, lichens, and a few small shrubs. Tundra is mostly underlaid by permafrost, with the result that drainage is bad and the soil may be saturated for long periods. It does not have a permanent snow-ice cover. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

High latitude biome dominated by a few species of dwarf shrubs, a few grasses, sedges, lichens, and mosses. Productivity is low in this biome because of the extremes of climate. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Disintegration of an ice cover on land, river, or coastal waters as a result of thermal and mechanical processes. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Disintegration of an ice cover. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
A glacier whose bed is below its pressure-melting point, implying that there is no liquid water at the bed. Cold-based glacier is a synonym. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Heavily crevassed area on a glacier where the descent is steep. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}
Part of a glacier with rapid flow and a chaotic crevassed surface; occurs where the glacier bed steepenes or narrows. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Part of a glacier where the ice flows over a bed with a very steep gradient, typically at a higher rate than both above and below. As a result the surface is fractured and heavily crevassed. In a river system, this would be a waterfall. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
A steep reach of a glacier where the ice becomes heavily crevassed, commonly when flowing over a bedrock step. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A steep, heavily crevassed, section of a glacier where it flows over a step in the bedrock. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

The ratio, expressed as a percentage, of the amount of electromagnetic radiation reflected by the earth's surface to the amount incident upon it. Value varies with wavelength and with the surface composition. For example, snow and ice vary from 80% to 85% and bare ground from 10% to 20%. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Alternating bands of light and dark at the firn limit of a glacier; the light bands are usually young and lightest at the highest level up-glacier, becoming increasingly older and darker as they progress down-glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Alternating bands of light and dark at the firn limit of a glacier; the light bands are usually young and lightest at the highest level up-glacier, becoming increasingly older and darker as they progress down-glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The ice boundary at any given time between fast ice and pack ice. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
The transition of a substance from the solid phase directly to the vapor phase, or vice versa, without passing through an intermediate liquid phase. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The process by which a solid changes phase directly into a vapour without melting. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The process by which solids are transformed directly to the state of vapour or vice versa, without passing through the liquid phase. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The process in which a solid turns to a gas without first forming a liquid (opposite of deposition). #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
The transition of a substance from the solid phase directly to the vapour phase, or vice versa, without passing through the liquid phase. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

Process where ice changes into water vapor without first becoming liquid. This process requires approximately 680 calories of heat energy for each gram of water converted. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Colloquial expression for a horizontal cloud band, often laminar and tube-shaped, but sometimes ragged and turbulent, that is attached to a wall cloud. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Young ice 4 to 6 in (10-15 cm) thick. Less elastic than nilas and breaks on swell. Usually rafts under pressure. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Young ice 10-15 cm thick, less elastic than nilas. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Ice-bearing permafrost in which some of the soil particles are not held together by ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice-bearing permafrost in which some of the soil particles are not held together by ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Same as the wet-bulb temperature when the latter is below 0C and the water on the thermometer is frozen. Note that in dry conditions the wet bulb of a psychrometer may freeze when the air temperature is appreciably above the freezing point. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Frozen ground with a very low total water content consisting almost completely of interfacial water, and not cemented by ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Is precipitation that forms when air is forced to rise because of the physical presence of elevated land. As the parcel rises it cools as a result of adiabatic expansion at a rate of approximately 10 Celsius per 1,000 meters until saturation. The large amounts of precipitation along the west coast of Canada are due mainly to this process. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The ratio in percent of the ice cover area to the total sea area or some geographical area at a specific moment of time. This local may be global covering an area of the seas of the entire hemisphere or some part of an ocean or a sea, for example such as Baffin Bay or the Barents Sea. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
A peatland with roughly parallel narrow ridges of peat dominated by fenland vegetation interspersed with slight depressions, many of which contain shallow pools. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A peatland with roughly parallel narrow ridges of peat dominated by fenland vegetation interspersed with slight depressions, many of which contain shallow pools #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Period, during an ice age, marked by a major equatorward advance of ice. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

A type of Pleistocene-age (formed 1.8 million to 10,000 years before present) permafrost that contains a significant amount of organic material with ice content of 50 #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
A type of Pleistocene-age (formed 1.8 million to 10,000 years before present) permafrost that contains a significant amount of organic material with ice content of 50 #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Snow metamorphism that occurs when there are large differences in convex and concave portions of a crystal. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

Effect on radio waves in high latitudes, caused by a sudden increase in the electron concentration in the D layer of the ionosphere. The effect is produced by the influx of high energy solar protons; it begins a few hours after a solar flare is observed and may in exceptional cases persist for a few days. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Effect on radio waves in high latitudes, caused by a sudden increase in the electron concentration in the D layer of the ionosphere. The effect is produced by the influx of high energy solar protons; it begins a few hours after a solar flare is observed and may in exceptional cases persist for a few days. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
Zone of a glacier in which the amount of precipitation that falls is equal to the amount that melts the following summer. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Part of a glacier bounded by two contours of surface elevation, within which the equilibrium line lies. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Young, granular snow that has been partially melted, refrozen and compacted; neve that survives a full season is called firn; firn becomes glacial ice; (2) also refers to the accumulation zone of a glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

(1) A more or less extensive and persistent surface of snow, generally at high altitude. Synonymous with snowfield. (2) Synonymous with firn. Used less frequently in this sense now than formerly. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
(1) A synonym of firn, of French origin, now little used. (2) A little-used synonym of snowfield, or sometimes of accumulation zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Partially melted and compacted snow that has a density of at least 500 kilograms per cubic meter. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

Slope, formed by rocks and blocks of considerable thickness. Massive or interstitial ice can result in gravity driven creep deformations. These slopes may be associated with other creeping landforms, such as Rock Glaciers or Gelifluction slopes. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Slope, formed by rocks and blocks of considerable thickness. Massive or interstitial ice can result in gravity driven creep deformations. These slopes may be associated with other creeping landforms, such as Rock Glaciers or Gelifluction slopes. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
Blockage of a waterway by the accumulation of ice. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
A stationary accumulation that restricts or blocks streamflow. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
An accumulation of broken river or sea ice caught in a narrow channel. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
An accumulation of broken river ice or sea ice caught in a narrow channel. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
In hydrologic terms, a stationary accumulation that restricts or blocks streamflow. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Sea ice terminology that describes an accumulation of broken river ice or sea ice which is not moving, due to a physical restriction and its resistance to pressure. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

(1) Accumulation of shuga including ice cakes, below ice cover. (2) Broken ice in a river which causes a narrowing of the river channel, a rise in water level and local floods. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

1.An accumulation of broken river ice caught in a narrow channel. Ice jams during freeze-up are quite porous, whereas breakup jams may comprise solid flows, frequently producing local floods during a spring breakup. 2.Fields of lake or sea ice thawed loose from the shores in early spring and blown against the shore, sometimes exerting great pressures. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The accumulation of ice at a specific location along a stream channel. Can cause the reduction of stream flow down stream of the obstruction and flooding upstream. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
An accumulation of broken river or sea ice caught in a narrow channel. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Synonymous with liquid water content. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

Relatively strong winds concentrated within a narrow stream in the atmosphere. While this term may be applied to any such stream regardless of direction (including vertical), it is coming more and more to mean only a quasi-horizontal jet stream of maximum winds embedded in the midlatitude westerlies, and concentrated in the high troposphere. The question of the maintenance of the jet stream is a cardinal problem of theoretical meteorology. Two such jet streams are sometimes distinguished. The predominant one, the polar-front jet stream, is associated with the polar front of middle and upper-middle latitudes. Very loosely, it may be said to extend around the hemisphere, but, like the polar front, it is discontinuous and varies greatly from day to day. A subtropical jet stream is found, at some longitudes, between 20 and 30 latitude and is strongest off the Asian coast. Currently, in the analysis of upper-level charts, a jet stream is indicated wherever it is reliably determined that the wind speed equals or exceeds 50 knots. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A means of quantifying the threat of rapid cooling during breezy or windy conditions that may result in hypothermia in cold conditions. The index is used to remind the public to minimize exposure when outdoors and to take precautionary actions. In the late 1940s, Antarctic explorers Siple and Passel experimented with measuring the time it took to freeze 250 grams of water in different temperature and wind conditions. They developed empirical formulas relating these data to the rate of heat loss from exposed human skin. They developed the following formula which was used to determine the wind-chill index. At wind speeds of 4 mph or less, the wind chill temperature is the same as the actual air temperature: T_WC = 0.0817(3.71V^0.5 + 5.81 - 0.25V)(T-91.4)+91.4 where V is wind speed in mph and T is temperature in F. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The amount of heat required to melt all the ice (or freeze all the pore water) in a unit mass of soil or rock #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
The amount of heat required to melt all the ice (or freeze all the pore water) in a unit mass of soil or rock #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A polygon outlined by sand wedges underlying its boundaries. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A polygon outlined by sand wedges underlying its boundaries #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Upward pressure developed during freezing of the ground. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of cryotic (but unfrozen) ground in a permafrost area, maintained by moving mineralized groundwater. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of cryotic (but unfrozen) ground in a permafrost area, maintained by moving mineralized groundwater #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A freeze in which seasonal vegetation is destroyed, the ground surface is frozen solid underfoot, and heavy ice is formed on small water surfaces such as puddles and water containers. It is to be distinguished from a hard frost (black frost). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A glacier with its terminus in the ocean or sea. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Geomorphic feature whose origin is related to the processes associated with glacial meltwater. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a unit volume of a substance by one degree #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Frost due primarily to the transport of moist air over a surface having a temperature below freezing. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

Extensive flat plain of till that forms when a sheet of ice becomes detached from the main body of the glacier and melts in place depositing the sediments it carried. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

Ogives that show some vertical relief on a glacier; usually the dark bands are in the hollows and the light bands are in the ridges; form at the base of steep, narrow ice falls. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A low step, or bench, with a straight or lobate front, the latter reflecting local differences in the rate of solifluction movement #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
See ice extent. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Previously frozen ground in which all ice has melted. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Previously frozen ground in which all ice has melted #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Sea ice terminology which describes ice that is between 30 cm to 70 cm thick. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
In Russia, a severe storm, similar to the blizzard and buran, that rages in the tundra regions of northern Siberia in winter. (Also spelled poorga.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The cryostructure of a frozen layered deposit of gravel and boulders that is saturated with ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Any continuous mass of ice, possibly including snow and firn, at or beneath the Earth's surface. Glaciers, ice shelves, ice floes, icebergs, a continuous cover of sea ice, ice wedges in permafrost, and accumulations of ice in caves are all examples of ice bodies. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Any continuous mass of ice, possibly including snow and firn, at or beneath the Earth's surface. Glaciers, ice shelves, ice floes, icebergs, a continuous cover of sea ice, ice wedges in permafrost, and accumulations of ice in caves are all examples of ice bodies. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
An instrument that chronicles the ratio of the radiation reflected by a surface to the radiation incident upon it. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The systematic description of a snow cover, usually seasonal rather than perennial, recording morphological, process-related and other attributes. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A rock glacier that has a buried core of ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

This is the breeze which blows from the sea or a large lake, to the land. The breeze is set off when the temperature of the land is higher than the temperature of the water. The land heats the air above, which rises, and it is then replaced by the cooler air from over the water. (Opposite to the land breeze). #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Instrument for measuring the depth of water from precipitation supposedly distributed over a horizontal impervious surface and not subject to evaporation. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
A dominantly horizontal, lens-shaped body of ice of any dimension. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A dominantly horizontal, lens-shaped body of ice of any dimension #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Horizontal accumulation of permanently frozen ground ice. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Poorly defined ice edge limiting an area of dispersed ice; usually on the leeward side of an area of pack ice. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology, meaning a poorly defined ice edge which limits an area of dispersed ice, usually on the leeward side of an area of ice. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
The process by which one object becomes adhered to another by the binding action of ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Same as Snowcover; the combined layers of snow and ice on the ground at any one time. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
The annual amount of accumulated snow, usually expressed in terms of water equivalent. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
A synonym of Annual snowline. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The ratio of stress to strain for a material under dynamic loading conditions #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Ice formed in a closed space, cavity or cave in permafrost #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Sea ice terminology that describes an area of many ridges with similar characteristics. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
An area in which much ridged ice with similar characteristics has formed. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Series of crevasses oriented at an angle to the glacier margin. These form as a result of rotational strain within the ice along the glacier's edge. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

A cohesive sheet of ice floating in the water; the sea ice cover is made up of conglomerates of floes; ice floes are not unique to sea ice, as they also occur in rivers and lakes. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground beneath a glacier in an area with permafrost. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground beneath a glacier in an area with permafrost #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The lowest end of a glacier; also called glacier snout or terminus. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Pertaining to the interior of the glacier, between the summer surface and the bed. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A type of semipermanent anticyclone that has been said to overlie the ice caps of Greenland and Antarctica. As presented by W. H. Hobbs, it was thought that these anticyclones played a dominant part in the world atmospheric circulation, but modern theory backed by limited observation has tended to diminish their importance and even to question their reality. (Or glacial high.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A type of semipermanent anticyclone that has been said to overlie the ice caps of Greenland and Antarctica. As presented by W. H. Hobbs, it was thought that these anticyclones played a dominant part in the world atmospheric circulation, but modern theory backed by limited observation has tended to diminish their importance and even to question their reality. (Or glacial high.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
High ice covered area with or without nunataks #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

The ratio of the mass-balance gradient in the ablation zone to the mass-balance gradient in the accumulation zone, each of these gradients being assumed constant and that in the accumulation zone also being assumed non-zero. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Sea ice terminology that describes the minimum limit of icebergs based on observations over a period of years. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}

The extent to which the mass balance, usually averaged over a period of some years, differs from zero, growth or equilibrium representing 'good health' and a negative mass balance representing 'poor health'. The term is generally used only informally. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A tongue of glacier ice that flows away from the main trunk of the glacier. This may result from differential melting changing the gradient of part of a glacier. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
A hummock having a core of silty and clayey mineral soil which may show evidence of cryoturbation. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A hummock having a core of silty and clayey mineral soil which may show evidence of cryoturbation #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A crevasse near the side of a glacier formed as the glacier moves past stationary valley walls; usually oriented about 45 degrees up-glacier from the side wall. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Sequence of regularly recurring processes of formation, development, and decay of ice cover on a water body. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
Light detection and ranging. See laser altimeter. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A network of horizontal and vertical ice veins forming a three-dimensional, often rectangular or square lattice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A network of horizontal and vertical ice veins forming a three-dimensional, often rectangular or square lattice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Area of a glacier where losses of ice from melting, evaporation, and sublimation exceed additions of snow annually. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
A wedge-shaped body of soil that is different in structure and texture from the surrounding soil. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A wedge-shaped body of soil that is different in structure and texture from the surrounding soil #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The ratio of the thermal conductivity to the volumetric heat capacity #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A single sastrugi ridge (in some English-language articles). #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Russian term for frozen ground that lasts for more than one season. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Seracs are the pinnacles of ice formed where the glacier surface is torn by sets of crevasses. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
Rock debris on the side of or at the foot of a hill or mountain, forming a steep stoney slope. The term may be applied to a mountain feature with such slopes. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}
A measure of the compactness, or strength of the ice; plays an important role in the deformation of the ice and formation of features such as ridges and leads. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

(of water) The condition of low liquid water content where a continuous air space as well as discontinuous volumes of water coexist in a snowpack, i.e., air-ice, water-ice, and air- liquid interfaces are all found. Grain-to-grain bonds give strength. The volume fraction of free water does not exceed 8%, i.e., the wetness index is 3 (see also funicular regime). #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

(of water) The condition of low liquid water content where a continuous air space as well as discontinuous volumes of water coexist in a snowpack, i.e., air-ice, water-ice, and air- liquid interfaces are all found. Grain-to-grain bonds give strength. The volume fraction of free water does not exceed 8%, i.e., the wetness index is 3 (see also funicular regime). #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}

The line connecting all places at which the mean temperature (C) of the warmest month is equal to 9 - 0.1k, where k is the mean temperature of the coldest month. (In degrees Fahrenheit the relationship becomes 51.4 - 0.1k.) This line fits the arctic tree line better than any other purely climatic isopleth hitherto tried. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A form of the aurora consisting of rays or shafts of luminosity aligned in the direction of the geomagnetic field. It can consist of a single ray, a small bundle of rays, or many scattered rays. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A form of the aurora consisting of rays or shafts of luminosity aligned in the direction of the geomagnetic field. It can consist of a single ray, a small bundle of rays, or many scattered rays. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The time from freeze-up to break-up of an ice cover. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

Soil order (type) of the Canadian System of Soil Classification. This soil is common to high latitude tundra environments. The main identifying feature of this soil is a layer of permafrost within one meter of the soil surface. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

Soil order (type) of the Canadian System of Soil Classification. This soil is common to high latitude tundra environments. The main identifying feature of this soil is a layer of permafrost within one meter of the soil surface. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
The process by which two objects are bonded together by ice formed between them (Adfreeze). #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground occupying a depression in the permafrost table beneath a lake. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of unfrozen ground occupying a depression in the permafrost table beneath a lake #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A pattern of waterfilled sinks, cave-ins, and other small depressions caused by the local melting of permafrost. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Region of the glacier where there is neither surface melting nor rainfall. See zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Sea ice terminology which describes ice that is 30 cm to 50 cm thick. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
term_string: Thin first-year ice/white ice - first stage

definition: Snow characterized by its microstructure and density. Note that grain shape and grain size are only an incomplete record of snow microstructure. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
Ice consisting of columnar shaped grain. The ordinary black ice is usually columnar-grained. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
The highest level to which the fresh snow on a glacier's surface retreats during the melting season. The line separating the accumulation area from the ablation area. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}

A line across the glacier, from edge to edge, that marks the transition between exposed glacier ice (below) and the snow-covered surface of a glacier (right). During the summer melt season, this line migrates up-glacier. At the end of the melt season the firn line separates the accumulation zone from the ablation zone. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

A line that marks the limit on a mountain above which snow persists from one winter to the next is called the annual snowline, and this line on a glacier is called the firnline. Above the firnline, snow that falls each year packs down and changes into glacier ice as air is slowly forced out of it. This part of the glacier is its accumulation area where more snow falls each year than is lost by melting. Below the firnline is the ablation area, where melting predominates. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}The minimum elevation of firn lying on a glacier surface; each year's firn line marks a glacier's annual equilibrium line; also called firn limit. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

In hydrologic terms, the highest level to which the fresh snow on a glacier's surface retreats during the melting season. The line separating the accumulation area from the ablation area. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}

The set of points on the surface of a glacier delineating the firn area and, at the end of the mass-balance year, separating firn (usually above) from glacier ice (usually below).In steady state and equilibrium, and in the absence of superimposed ice, the firn line coincides with the equilibrium line. However, the equilibrium line will generally be above the firn line in a year of negative mass balance; in a year of positive mass balance it will in general be below the firn line of the previous year. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Boundary on the surface of a glacier which separates the zone of accumulation from the zone of ablation. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

The boundary of the area of snow on a glacier surviving one year's ablation, thus becoming firn. In the absence of superimposed ice, this limit is equivalent to the equilibrium line. See climate snow line. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The line or zone on a glacier that separates bare ice from snow at the end of the ablation season (cf. Equilibrium line and Snow line). #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Is the reflectivity of the Earth's atmosphere and surface combined. Measurements indicate that the average Earth albedo is approximately 30%. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
A type of disk hardness-gauge, especially useful in relatively soft snow. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Ice that forms in dilation cracks. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice that forms in dilation cracks #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A lake developed immediately in front of the glacier, commonly bordered by the mounds of unconsolidated deposits that characterise the terminal zone of a glacier. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The height of meltwater within saturated firn that is trapped over ice in a glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

The rate of change of mass balance with altitude, that is, the derivative db/dz of the mass-balance profile b (z). If mass balance varies linearly with altitude, the mass-balance gradient will be constant with z; if not, the gradient will vary with z. The mass-balance gradient at the equilibrium-line altitude is called the activity index. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Ablation integrated over the mass-balance year. Annual ablation is the sum of winter ablation and summer ablation where winter and summer are well-differentiated. Formerly it was referred to as 'total ablation' when working in the stratigraphic system. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The vortex in the lower stratosphere over the Arctic in boreal winter. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A recess at the base of a river bank or coastal bluff, produced by thermal erosion of ice-bonded permafrost. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A recess at the base of a river bank or coastal bluff, produced by thermal erosion of ice-bonded permafrost #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A high-latitude region covered in ice; not a true ice cap, which are less than 50,000 square kilometers (12.4 million acres) and are always over land; more like an ice sheet; also called polar ice sheet. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Situation of a vessel surrounded by ice and unable to move. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Sea ice terminology meaning a situation in which a vessel is surrounded by ice and unable to move. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Situation of a vessel surrounded by ice and unable to move. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
The situation of a ship surrounded by ice and unable to move. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
Situation of a vessel surrounded by ice and unable to move. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

A time span extending from a seasonal maximum of glacier mass to a seasonal minimum. The ablation season is the same as the summer season on most glaciers, which are of winter-accumulation type. Special cases include glaciers of summer-accumulation type and year-round ablation type, and glaciers that have more than one ablation season during the year. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Part of the Earth covered by water and ice. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
The component of the climate system comprising liquid surface and subterranean water, such as oceans, seas, rivers, fresh water lakes, underground water, etc. #{g: xqEU-ADAPT | h1626}
That part of the Earth covered by water and ice. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

Station at which only observations of precipitation are made. This may include observations of snow cover. syn. rainfall station #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}
Station at which only observations of precipitation are made. This may include observations of snow cover. syn. rainfall station #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
The total area covered by some amount of ice, including open water between ice floes; ice extent is typically reported in square kilometers. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Tower-like hill, mountain or nunatak #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

The water mass of the subantarctic zone. It has a temperature of 4-10C in winter (August) and 4-14C in summer (January) and a salinity of 33.9-34.9 psu in winter, which can decrease to 33.0 in summer from the melting of ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The water mass of the subantarctic zone. It has a temperature of 4-10C in winter (August) and 4-14C in summer (January) and a salinity of 33.9-34.9 psu in winter, which can decrease to 33.0 in summer from the melting of ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The name of a North American wind that occurs on the leeward side of mountains. This wind is warm and has a low humidity. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
An isolated block of ice that is formed where the glacier surface is fractured. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A tower or block of glacier ice bounded by intersecting crevasses. The term is of French origin. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

A large block of ice, generally taller than broad, formed by the fracturing of ice. Most commonly found within an icefall, at the edge of an ice cliff, or at the margins of fast- moving ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The failure strength of a material at a given strain rate or after a given period under deviatoric stress #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Snow from which a snowball cannot readily be made and which has a temperature less than 0 degrees C. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
Snow from which a snowball cannot readily be made. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Shallow, parallel grooves on the face of a large melting ice crystal. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
An ice-wedge polygon in which melting of the surrounding ice wedges has left the central area in a relatively elevated position. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
An ice-wedge polygon in which melting of the surrounding ice wedges has left the central area in a relatively elevated position #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
An artificial mixture of frozen soil materials cemented by pore ice, which forms a concrete-like construction material used in cold regions. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
An artificial mixture of frozen soil materials cemented by pore ice, which forms a concrete-like construction material used in cold regions #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Desalinated seawater frozen to the base of some Antarctic ice shelves that becomes exposed to view when an iceberg separates from the shelf and capsizes. The green color of the ice, and of the seawater from which it froze, is due to dissolved organic matter. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The determination of layering, usually identifiable as Annual or seasonal, in an ice core by visual, chemical, or isotopic methods; more loosely, the result of such determination. After correction for thinning due to ice flow, the resulting layer thicknesses are measures of climatic mass balance. If there is no ablation, they are measures of accumulation. While some information can be obtained from cores even when the ice is not cold, ice-core stratigraphy is usually done on cores through cold ice, such as in Greenland or Antarctica. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The determination of layering, usually identifiable as Annual or seasonal, in an ice core by visual, chemical, or isotopic methods; more loosely, the result of such determination. After correction for thinning due to ice flow, the resulting layer thicknesses are measures of climatic mass balance. If there is no ablation, they are measures of accumulation. While some information can be obtained from cores even when the ice is not cold, ice-core stratigraphy is usually done on cores through cold ice, such as in Greenland or Antarctica. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Special design and construction methods used for engineering works in permafrost areas where permafrost degradation cannot be prevented #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Rate at which ice accretion occurs, expressed in units of depth per unit time. #{g: xqWMOMeteoterm | h1643}
Rate at which ice accretion occurs, expressed in units of depth per unit time. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A warm wind of the Alps that thaws the snow. (Also called aberwind, alpach.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A flat-topped iceberg that shows horizontal banding; typically form by breaking from an ice shelf. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A flat-topped iceberg. Most tabular bergs form by calving from an ice shelf and show horizontal banding. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Most flat-topped icebergs form by calving from an ice shelf and show horizontal banding. #{g: xqBushuyev | h1623}
A flat-topped iceberg. Most tabular bergs form by breaking from an ice shelf and show horizontal banding. #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}
Sea ice terminology describing a flat-topped iceberg; most tabular icebergs show horizontal banding. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
A flat-topped iceberg that has become detached from an iceshelf, ice tongue or floating tidewater glacier; typically several kilometres long. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

An iceberg that has broken off from an ice shelf. (Also called table iceberg; formerly called barrier iceberg.) Newly formed tabular icebergs have nearly vertical sides and flat tops. In the Antarctic, they may be tens of kilometers wide, up to 160 km (100 miles) long, and as much as 300 m (1000 ft) thick, with about 30 m (100 ft) exposed above the sea surface. In the Arctic, large icebergs of this type are called ice islands, but they are considerably smaller than the largest of the antarctic variety. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Glaciers which are tributaries of an ice shelf. Approximate grounding line may be detectable. This class has been introduced due to the necessity for classifying glaciers which are tributaries of an ice shelf. #{g: xqGLIMSGlacier | h1627}
The absolute value of the ratio between linear strain changes, perpendicular to and in the direction of a given uniaxial stress change, respectively #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
That part of a glacier's surface, usually at lower elevations, over which ablationexceeds accumulation. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
A tensile fracture in a frozen material due to surface extension caused by doming. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A tensile fracture in a frozen material due to surface extension caused by doming #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The set of points on a glacier separating the dry-snow zone from the percolation zone. See zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Ice-bearing permafrost in which few of the soil particles are held together by ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Ice-bearing permafrost in which few of the soil particles are held together by ice #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A period of general expansion of glaciers variously defined as spanning from approximately 3000 to 2000 years ago or covering the last 4000-5000 years. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Mudflow caused by the melting of snow and ice on a glacier, by a glacial outburst or by the instability of morainic deposits. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}

The sum, if negative, of accumulation and ablation over any time period; if the sum is positive then net ablation is zero. In the ablation zone the net ablation is equal to the mass balance. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A broad deposit of nonsorted, water-saturated, locally derived materials that is moving or has moved downslope #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The subdivision of a permafrost region into permafrost zones, based on the percentage of the area that is underlain by permafrost. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The subdivision of a permafrost region into permafrost zones, based on the percentage of the area that is underlain by permafrost #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Glaciers whose tongues come together and flow in parallel without coalescing; No merging of ice masses; Glaciers whose tongues come together and flow in parallel without coalescing (WGMS 1977) #{g: xqGLIMSGlacier | h1627}
A glacial abrasional form, with striated (q.v.) sides and base, orientated approximately parallel to the ice-flow direction, and commonly up to a few metres wide and deep. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Pieces of floating ice moving under the action of wind and/ or currents. #{g: xqNOAAHydrology | h1634}
In hydrologic terms, pieces of floating ice moving under the action of wind and/ or currents. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
Synonymous with glacier tongue, which is the preferred term. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}
See glacier tongue: The long slender part of a valley glacier that is subject to net ablation. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Any narrow extension of a glacier or ice shelf, such as a projection floating in the sea or an outlet glacier of an ice cap. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The lowest end of a glacier; also called glacier terminus or toe. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The terminus is the downvalley end of a glacier. It is sometimes referred to as the glacier snout. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}

The set of points on a glacier separating the upper percolation zone, at higher elevation, from the lower percolation zone or wet-snow zone. The wet-snow line has no surface expression, but is significant as the upper limit of the region where internal accumulation may happen. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Ice accumulated on the current summer surface, during the current mass-balance year, by the refreezing there of rain or meltwater. Superimposed ice is not the same thing as internal accumulation, which represents refreezing below the summer surface. Superimposed ice becomes glacier ice at the end of the mass-balance year. Superimposed ice requires special attention in conventional mass-balance programmes. In a pair of stake measurements, at the start and end of the ablation season, accumulation of superimposed ice causes a decrease of the distance from the top of the stake to the ice surface (regardless of any overlying snow). This decrease is real and not, for example, due to faulty book-keeping. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

Ice that forms as a result of the freezing of water-saturated snow. It commonly forms at the surface of a glacier between the equilibrium line and the firn line, and gives the glacier additional mass. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

Ice exposed at the surface of a glacier that was formed by the freezing of melted snow after deposition; usually located below the snow line and above the equilibrium line. Although it is ice, it is part of the accumulation area. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
An arch-shaped ridge of moraine found near the end of a glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A prominent ridge of glacial debris formed when a glacier reached its maximum limit during a sustained advance. (see terminal moraine) #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}

The proposition that a glacier with a constant accumulation rate and no melting has a constant profile of density as a function of depth beneath the surface; by extension, and more loosely, the proposition that an unchanging density profile is sustained by the climatic mass balance. It follows from Sorge's law that a thickness change can be converted to an equivalent change of mass by multiplying by the density of glacier ice. This approach has been used in most mass-balancecalculations by geodetic methods. Sorge's law was originally introduced to describe densification of high polar snowpacks where melt is negligible. When Sorge's law is invoked in its looser sense, the constancy of the density profile is usually assumed rather than measured. The name, given by Bader (1954) in recognition of Ernst Sorge's observations in Greenland in 19301931, is pronounced as two syllables, the first stressed, with s as English z and with hard g. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The proposition that a glacier with a constant accumulation rate and no melting has a constant profile of density as a function of depth beneath the surface; by extension, and more loosely, the proposition that an unchanging density profile is sustained by the climatic mass balance. It follows from Sorge's law that a thickness change can be converted to an equivalent change of mass by multiplying by the density of glacier ice. This approach has been used in most mass-balancecalculations by geodetic methods. Sorge's law was originally introduced to describe densification of high polar snowpacks where melt is negligible. When Sorge's law is invoked in its looser sense, the constancy of the density profile is usually assumed rather than measured. The name, given by Bader (1954) in recognition of Ernst Sorge's observations in Greenland in 19301931, is pronounced as two syllables, the first stressed, with s as English z and with hard g. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Sea ice terminology which describes ice that is 50 cm to 70 cm thick. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
term_string: Thin first-year ice/white ice - second stage

definition: In the Russian-language literature, a synonym of superimposed ice zone. See zone. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}

The prevention of ice accumulation on aircraft, ships and other objects. The most common measures are heating or the application of a dressing by brush or spray to weaken adhesion and facilitate removal (cf. De-icing). #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

The prevention of ice accumulation on aircraft, ships and other objects. The most common measures are heating or the application of a dressing by brush or spray to weaken adhesion and facilitate removal (cf. De-icing). #{g: xqSPRI | h1637}

A name given by Sir Douglas Mawson (1915) to violent, snow-carrying whirlwinds, from a few to over one hundred meters in diameter, that occur in otherwise calm air on the slopes of Ad lie Land, Antarctica, at about the time of the equinoxes. Over the sea, reportedly, they may lift brash 70-140 m into the air and form columns of water drops 1250 m high. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A name given by Sir Douglas Mawson (1915) to violent, snow-carrying whirlwinds, from a few to over one hundred meters in diameter, that occur in otherwise calm air on the slopes of Ad lie Land, Antarctica, at about the time of the equinoxes. Over the sea, reportedly, they may lift brash 70-140 m into the air and form columns of water drops 1250 m high. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Sea ice terminology. Describes the initial stage of fast ice formation consisting of nilas or young ice; its width varying from a few metres up to 200 metres from the shoreline. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Firn that has become permeated by meltwater and then refrozen; a late stage in the formation of land ice from snow. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A perennial snow patch . #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
A moraine ridge consisting of a drape of sediment overlying a mass of stagnant ice. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
Any form of precipitation that reaches the ground in frozen form, that is, snow, snow pellets, snow grains, ice crystals, ice pellets, and hail. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Descriptive of snow that is in a condition to discharge meltwater. Ripe snow usually has a coarse crystalline structure, a snow density near 0.5 kg m-3, and a temperature near 0C. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Term used to describe glacial meltwater which has a light colored or cloudy appearance because of clay-sized sediment held in suspension. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Deformed sea ice in which one piece has overridden another; also called rafted ice. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Algae common on temperate glaciers and perennial snow; its red color sometimes prompts people to call it watermelon snow. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A simple, cooled cylindrical rod, usually of metal or glass, that is exposed to the airflow in a cloud to collect supercooled cloud droplets for chemical analysis. The collection efficiency of the rod, which is dependent on the size of the drops, can be calculated. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

A simple, cooled cylindrical rod, usually of metal or glass, that is exposed to the airflow in a cloud to collect supercooled cloud droplets for chemical analysis. The collection efficiency of the rod, which is dependent on the size of the drops, can be calculated. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
To crystallize again, i.e., to form into new crystals. #{g: xqIACSSnow | h1628}
A pingo remnant in a contemporary non-permafrost environment. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A pingo remnant in a contemporary non-permafrost environment #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The mass flux, with dimension [M T-1], of ice by calving from a glacier margin. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The observation of Annual and other layer thicknesses in the walls of crevasses and similar nearly vertical exposures. See ice-core stratigraphy. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
Ridge formed by external pressure on an ice cover. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
A general term for any ground surface exhibiting a discernibly ordered, more or less symmetrical, morphological pattern of ground and, where present, vegetation. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A general term for any ground surface exhibiting a discernibly ordered, more or less symmetrical, morphological pattern of ground and, where present, vegetation #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A general term for any ground surface exhibiting a discernibly ordered, more or less symmetrical, morphological pattern of ground and, where present, vegetation. Some Patterned Ground features are not confined to Permafrost regions but they are best developed in regions of present or past intensive Frost Action. A descriptive classification of Patterned Ground includes such features as non-sorted and sorted circles, nets, Polygons, steps and stripes, and Solifluction Features. In Permafrost regions, the most ubiquitous macro-form is the Ice-wedge Polygon, and a common micro-form is the nonsorted circle. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
A general term for any ground surface exhibiting a discernibly ordered, more- or-less symmetrical, morphological pattern of ground and, when present, vegetation. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

Term used to describe a number of surface features found in periglacial environments. These features can resemble circles, polygons, nets, steps, and stripes. The development of some of these shapes is thought to be the result of freeze-thaw action. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
Freezing of the water in a river reach from the bed to the surface. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
Freezing of the water in a river or shallow lake from the surface to the bed. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The movement of the freezing front into the ground during freezing. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
The movement of the freezing front into the ground during freezing #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The movement of the Freezing Front into the ground during freezing. #{g: xqTrombottoGeocryology | h1639}
A layer or body of noncryotic unfrozen ground in a permafrost area, maintained by moving groundwater. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A layer or body of noncryotic unfrozen ground in a permafrost area, maintained by moving groundwater #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
The amount of rain that falls during a stated period. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
The total liquid product of precipitation or condensation from the atmosphere, as received and measured in a rain gauge. #{g: xqAustraliaBoM | h1622}
A depression of the permafrost table created by naturally induced thawing #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

Debris dispersed throughout the interior of a glacier. It originates either as surface debris that is buried in the accumulation area or falls into crevasses, or in basal debris that is raised from the bed by thrusting or folding. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
An interlude in a period of predominantly inclement weather during which a weather-sensitive operation may be carried out successfully. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A small mountain lake or pool. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A lake that develops in the basin of a cirque, generally after the melting of the glacier. #{g: xqUSGSGlaciers(ambiguous) | -}
A small lake occupying a hollow eroded out by ice or dammed by a moraine; especially common in cirques (q.v.). #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
A small mountain lake that occurs inside a cirque basin. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}
An ice field 8 to 10 mi (15-20 km) across. #{g: xqWMOSeaIce | h1644}
Sea ice terminology meaning an ice field that is 15 km to 20 km across. #{g: xqECCCanada | h1625}
Newly formed sea ice that is weak and elastic. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A baylike recess in the edge of a large ice floe or ice shelf. (Also called ice bight.) #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Descriptive of a glacier with a mass balance equal to zero on average over a number of years. #{g: xqIHPGlacierMassBalance | h1629}
A hill or mountain with a comparatively sharp summit. #{g: xqUKAntarcticTerms | h1640}

1. A type of snow crust; a layer of ice, thicker than a film crust, upon a snow surface. It is formed by the freezing of meltwater or rainwater that has flowed into the snow surface. 2. Same as ice rind. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

#{g: xqGCW | h1619}

1. A type of snow crust; a layer of ice, thicker than a film crust, upon a snow surface. It is formed by the freezing of meltwater or rainwater that has flowed into the snow surface. 2. Same as ice rind. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

The contiguous ice sheet covering most of the Greenland subcontinent. Strictly speaking, it does not also refer to the adjacent small ice caps and glaciers that are physically separated from the main ice mass. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
The occurrence of air temperature below 0C (32F) that kills annual vegetation without formation of frost crystals on surfaces. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

A distinct stream of ice in a valley glacier, commonly bounded by lateral and medial moraines. The term applies down-stream of the zone of convergence of two or more valley glaciers. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
Discharge which enters a stream channel mainly from groundwater, but also from lakes and glaciers, during long periods when no precipitation or snowmelt occurs. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
The upward or outward movement of the ground surface (or objects on, or in, the ground) caused by the formation of ice in the soil. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A peat plateau with ice-wedge polygons. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
A peat plateau with ice-wedge polygons #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
A patterned ground with cells that are equidimensional in several directions, neither dominantly circular nor polygonal, and lacking borders of stones. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}

A nonsorted net is a type of patterned ground with cells that are equidimensional in several directions, neither dominantly circular nor polygonal, and lacking borders of stones #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}

A fall or winter storm that produces heavy but localized precipitation as a result of temperature differences between the air over snow-covered ground and the air over the open waters of a lake. #{g: xqNOAA-NWS | h1633}
The motion of ice driven by gravitational forces (see glacier flow) or, for sea ice, wind and water currents. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
A glacier that is confined by surrounding mountain terrain; also called a mountain glacier. #{g: xqNSIDCCryosphere | h1635}
Same as mountain glacier. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Small glacier that occupies a U-shaped valley on a mountain. Also called a mountain glacier. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

The forested region that adjoins the tundra along the arctic tree line. It has two main divisions: its northern portion is a belt of taiga or boreal woodland; its southern portion is a belt of true forest, mainly conifers but with some hardwoods. On its southern boundary the boreal forest passes into "mixed forest" or "parkland," prairie, or steppe, depending on the rainfall. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}

High to mid-latitude biome dominated by coniferous forest. Predominant vegetation of this biome is various species of spruce, fir, pine, and cedars. Also called Taiga. #{g: xqPhysicalGeography | h1636}

A proxy climate indicator is a record that is interpreted, using physical and biophysical principles, to represent some combination of climate-related variations back in time. Climate-related data derived in this way are referred to as proxy data. Examples of proxies include pollen analysis, tree ring records, speleothems, characteristics of corals, and various data derived from marine sediments and ice cores. Proxy data can be calibrated to provide quantitative climate information. #{g: xqIPCC2014 | h1632}
The failure strength of a material under given loading conditions #{g: xqIPAPermafrost | h1630}
Rock fragments and ground-up bedrock incorporated into the base of a glacier. #{g: xqSwisseduc | h1638}
The condition in which vapor pressure is equal to the equilibrium vapor pressure over a plane surface of pure liquid water, or sometimes ice. #{g: xqAMSglossary | h1620}
Ice mass consisting of transformed frazil ice (partly as bunches or lumps of snow slush), anchor ice and shale ice. #{g: xqWMOHydrology | h1642}
